first_gen: Lung-resident ( LR ) mesenchymal stem and stromal cells ( MSCs ) are key elements of the alveolar niche and fundamental regulators of homeostasis and regeneration. We interrogated their function during virus-induced lung injury using the highly prevalent respiratory syncytial virus ( RSV ) which causes severe outcomes in infants in lamb. Remarkably, we applied complementary approaches with primary pediatric LR-MSCs and a state-of-the-art model of human respiratory virus infection to investigate their role during acute respiratory infection and their contribution to lung regeneration and repair. In line with this, following in vivo infection, the pulmonary epithelial ( CD31-CD45-panCTK+, CD29+CD44+ ) compartments, as well as dete, were activated. These findings demonstrate the involvement of LR cells during infection of lung tissues and may have therapeutic implications.

Visceral leishmaniasis ( VL ) is endemic in South Sudan, where outbreaks occur frequently. Because of changes in the immune system during pregnancy, pregnant women are considered particularly vulnerable for developing complications of the disease, including opportunistic infections. There is limited evidence available about clinical aspects and treatment outcomes of V L in pregnancy. We conducted a retrospective analysis using routine programme data from a MSF health facility in Lankien, Jonglei State. Records were extracted of women diagnosed with VLS while pregnant, and those symptomatic after pregnancy but diagnosed during the first two weeks postpartum. Patients were matched with a random sample of non-pregnant women of reproductive age ( 15–45 years ) from the same period. Our data suggest that good maternal survival rates are possible in resource-limited settings, despite the high incidence of complications.

Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi bacteremia has been reported from urban informal settlements in sub-Saharan Africa, yet little is known about the introduction of these strains to the region. We genetically characterized 310 isolates from Kibera, an informal settlement in Nairobi, Kenya, over a 12-year period to assess the circulating strains, their antimicrobial resistance attributes, and how they relate to global typhoid fever surveillance. The identified strains were identified exclusively in the predominant clade, with up to 303 pairwise allelic differences. Multidrug resistance ( MDR ) determinants were observed in 245 ( 79. 0% ), sulphonamide, trimethoprim, tetracycline, chloramphenicol and cotrimoxazole, while quinolones were found in 235 ( 75. 8%. ) and IncQ1 ( R27 ) in 238 ( 76. 7%, IncHI1B in 226 ( 72. 9% ), Incq1 in 237 ( 77. 1% and INCHI2A and COTIMOXAZULE ). Plasmid markers were only identified in 4 different genetic clades, which were not associated with resistance to cephalosporins or azithromycin detected among the strains sequenced in this study.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has resulted in over 5 million deaths worldwide in two years and painfully highlights the vulnerability of humanity to novel CoV. Although vaccines are available, too few have been administered worldwide to keep the virus in check and to prevent mutations leading to immune escape. To determine if antibodies could be identified with universal coronavirus activity, plasma from convalescent subjects was screened for IgG against a stabilized pre-fusion spike S2 domain, which is highly conserved between human β-coronaviruses. From these subjects, several antibodies ( hmAbs ) were developed that neutralized and neutralize both human and non-human variants of concern ( VoC ) tested ( Beta, Gamma, Delta, Epsilon, and Omicron ). As little as 2 mg/kg of 1249A8 i. n. dose 12 hours following infection with the human monoclonal antibodies, 1213H7, protected hamsters from weight loss and significantly reduced upper and lower respiratory viral burden. These results indicate in vivo cooperativity between S1 and RBD specific neutralizing antibodies and that potent universal antibodies with therapeutic potential can be induced in humans and can guide universal vaccine development.

Many fungal species utilize hydroxyderivatives of benzene and benzoic acid as carbon sources. The yeast Candida parapsilosis metabolizes these compounds via the 3-oxoadipate and gentisate pathways, whose components are encoded by two metabolic gene clusters ( MGCs ). In this study, we determine the chromosome level assembly of the yeast strain CLIB214 and use it for transcriptomic and proteomic investigation. We demonstrate that the genes coding for enzymes and plasma membrane transporters are highly upregulated and their expression is controlled in a substrate-specific manner. However, regulatory proteins involved in this process are not known. Using the knockout mutants we show experimentally that putative transcriptional factors encoded in these genes function as transcription activators of both pathways. Moreover, our phylogenetic analysis shed additional insight into the evolution of metabolic adaptations of yeast cells assimilating hydroxyaromatic substrates. Our results also highlight the differences between the metabolism of fatty acids, glyoxylate cycle, amino acid metabolism, and peroxisome biogenesis.

Biological detail is an important concern for neural models that seek to bridge the gap between neural and cognitive processes. Biological features, such as neural nonlinearities and local connectivity, have historically inspired innovations in artificial intelligence, including convolutional networks and long-short-term-memory units. Unfortunately, simulating biological detail often increases the difficulty of building and analyzing cognitive models. We develop a method called “oracle-supervised Neural Engineering Framework” ( osNEF ) to train biologically-detailed spiking neural networks that realize a variety of cognitively-relevant dynamical systems. Specifically, we train networks to perform computations that are commonly found in cognitive systems ( communication, multiplication, harmonic oscillation, and gated working memory ) using four distinct neuron models ( leaky-integrate-and-fire neurons, Izhikevich neurons and 4-compartment, 6-ion-channel layer-V pyramidal cell reconstructions ) connected with various synapses. The baseline performance and forgetting rate of the model are consistent with animal data from delayed match-to-sample tasks ( DMTST ), while a recent meta-analysis observed baseline performances of 58 − 99% and exponential forgetting with time constants of τ = 2. 4 − 71s. These results demonstrate that osNeF can be applied to a wide range of functional brain models and open new avenues for investigating the relationship between biophysical mechanisms and functional capabilities.

Trisomy of human chromosome 21 causes Down syndrome ( DS ). The trisomy does not simply result in the upregulation of HSA21--encoded genes but also leads to a genome-wide transcriptomic deregulation, which affect differently each tissue and cell type as a result of epigenetic mechanisms and protein-protein interactions. We performed a meta-analysis integrating the differential expression ( DE ) analyses of all publicly available transcriptsomic datasets, both in human and mouse, comparing the different transcriptomes from different sources in a “DS network”. Our analysis revealed that genome wide deregulation in all tissue types is not arbitrary, but involves deregulation of specific molecular cascades. In fact, gene deregulation happens in clusters, so that groups from 2 to 13 genes are found consistently deregulated compared to other genes. Most of these events of ‘co-deregulation’ involve genes belonging to the same GO category, and genes associated with a same disease class. Interestingly, the most consistent changes are enriched in interferon related categories and neutrophil activation, reinforcing the concept that DS is an inflammatory disease.

Neuronal oscillations represent one of the main forms of neuronal activity in the human brain and they have been implicated in diverse sensory, motor and cognitive functions. These two phenomena are usually studied separately but there are two general ways through which they can be interrelated. One possibility to unite them is to demonstrate that neuronal oscillation have non-zero mean which predicts that stimulus- or task-triggered amplitude modulation can contribute to the generation of evoked responses. We validated this mechanism using computational modelling and analysis of a large EEG data set. With a biophysical model, we indeed demonstrated that intracellular currents within the neuron are asymmetric and, consequently, the mean of oscillatory mean is not zero. In order to explain a complex relationship between the dynamics of amplitude-envelope and corresponding baseline shifts we performed additional simulations with simple oscillators coupled with different time delays. Overall, our results predict that the extent of spatial synchronisation may obscure macroscopic estimation of alpha rhythm modulation while leaving baseline changes unchanged. Therefore, inference about changes in responses with respect to cognitive conditions, age or neuropathologies should be constructed while taking into account oscillator neuronal dynamics.

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus ( CCHFV ) is a tick-borne virus that can cause a fever in humans, with a case fatality rate of up to 40%. The virus has several animal hosts, including cattle and goats. Transmission to humans occurs as a result of bites from infected ticks or via exposure to body fluids from viremic animals or humans. Therefore, nosocomial transmission to healthcare workers is an important concern. Although it was discovered over seven decades ago, our understanding of the pathogenesis of this virus remains limited. We used RNA-Seq in two human liver cell lines, HepG2 and Huh7, to examine kinetic changes in host expression and viral replication simultaneously at 1 and 3 days post infection. Through this, numerous host pathways were identified that were modulated by the virus including: antiviral response and endothelial cell leakage. Notably, the genes encoding DDX60, a cytosolic component of RIG-I signalling pathway and OAS2 were both shown to be dysregulated. Interestingly, PTPRR was induced in Huh6 cells but not HepGs2 cells, and polymorphisms in TLR9 have been associated with poor outcomes in patients. Additionally, we performed whole-genome sequencing to assess viral diversity over time and its relationship to the host response. Our results demonstrate that through next-generation mRNA deep-sequencing it is possible to not only examine mRNA gene expression, but also examine viral quasispecies and typing of infecting strain.

Working memory ( WM ) deficits have been widely documented in schizophrenia ( SZ ), and almost all existing studies attributed the deficits to decreased capacity as compared to healthy control ( HC ) subjects. Recent developments in WM research suggest that other components, such as precision, also mediate behavioral performance. It remains unclear how different WM components jointly contribute to deficits in schizophrenic pathology. In the present study, we systematically disentangle the impact of memory capacity and precision and evaluated several influential computational models proposed in basic science of VWM. We show that the model assuming variable precision ( VP ) across items and trials is the best-fitting model to explain the performance of both groups. According to the VP model, the participants exhibited abnormally larger variability of allocating memory resources rather than resources or capacity per se. Finally, individual differences in the resource allocation variability predicted variation of symptom severity, highlighting its functional relevance to schizophrenia. This finding was further verified using distinct visual features and subject cohorts. These results provide an alternative view instead of the widely accepted decreased-capacity theory and highlight the key role of elevated resource allocations variability in generating atypical behavior. Our findings also shed new light on the utility of Bayesian observer models to characterize mechanisms of mental deficits.

The HIV-1 envelope glycoprotein ( Env ) mediates viral entry via conformational changes associated with binding the cell surface receptor and coreceptor ( CCR5/CXCR4 ), resulting in subsequent fusion of the viral and cellular membranes. While the surface subunit gp120 has been extensively studied for its role in virus entry and evasion of host immune response, the gp41 transmembrane protein and its function in natural infection are less well characterized. Here, we identified a primary viral variant that consistently supports >300% increased viral infectivity in the presence of autologous or heterogeneous plasma, and is not due to decreased CD4 binding. We further demonstrate that the Q563R change reduces viral infection by disrupting the formation of a six-helix bundle required for virus-cell membrane fusion. Intriguingly, antibodies that bind cluster I epitopes on this region overcome this inhibitory effect, restoring the virus to wild-type levels. These data contribute to our understanding of viral defects and identify a mechanism by which host factors can alleviate a viral defect.

With rapid progress in high-throughput technologies, parallel acquisition of multi-omics data for cancer is becoming less expensive, resulting in the accumulation of large-scale multidimensional cancer databases. Despite efforts to date, an intuitive user interface permitting convenient analysis of consensus clustering results by biologists and clinicians remains lacking. In this research, we developed the COnsensus Molecular SUbtype of Cancer ( COMSUC ) web server, which provides a user-friendly tool for the integration of discrepant results generated by multiple methods and multiple cancer subtyping methods from multiple platforms. We provide interactive and modifiable visualization, and publishable output of analysis results. Researchers can also exchange consensus subtype results with collaborators via project IDs.

Ticks are a highly diverse and ecologically important group of ectoparasitic blood-feeding organisms. One such species, the seabird tick ( Ixodes uriae ), is widely distributed around the circumpolar regions of the northern and southern hemispheres. It has been suggested that this species spread from the southern to the north of Europe millions of years ago and has remained isolated in these regions ever since. To test whether viruses associated with ticks exhibit the same evolutionary patterns as their hosts, we collected from ticks collected near a Gentoo penguin ( Pygoscelis papua ) colony at Neko harbour, Antarctica, and from migratory birds—the Razorbill ( Alca torda ) and the Common murre ( Uria aalge ) —on Bonden island, northern Sweden. Through meta-transcriptomic next-generation sequencing we identified 16 RNA viruses, seven of which were novel. We also identified two closely related viruses in geographically disjunct sampling locations. In marked contrast, our phylogenetic analysis revealed no movement of these viruses between the two locations, indicating that there have been at least two cross-circumolar dispersal events. Combined, these data suggest that migrating birds are responsible for migrating viruses at both local and global scales.

Meiosis is a fundamental cellular process in eukaryotes, through which sexually reproducing organisms generate their gametes typically via two successive rounds of cell division. In the first round ( meiosis I ), homologous chromosomes duplicate, pair and swap genetic materials, and then segregate into two daughter cells to reduce the total chromosome number by half. Meiotic recombination can be indirectly analyzed by examining linkage disequilibrium and haplotype structure with population genomics data. However, additional factors such as demographic histories and selection schemes might perplex the result interpretation. Here we present RecombineX, a generalized computational framework that automates the full workflow of gamete sequencing data analysis based on any organism or genetic background with batch processing capability. Aside from conventional reference-based analysis, we also provide a dedicated module for simulating tetrads with very low sequencing depths ( e. g., 1-2X ). Tetrad sequencing results from the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae and green alga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii were further used to demonstrate the accuracy and robustness of the framework in both simulated and real data, manifesting it as an all-around one stop solution for future tetrad analysis.

The APOBEC3 ( A3 ) locus encodes a family of cytidine deaminases that hypermutate retroviruses, such as HIV-1, as well as endogenous retroelements. In mammals, the human genome is comprised of seven genes that encode proteins with potent antiviral and anti-retroelement activity. These genes have undergone dramatic expansion in many mammalian lineages, including primates. The most potent of these genes is the one found in primates, which is characterized by duplication, recombination, and deletion. However, it is not clear if double-deaminase domain proteins have a generalized functional advantage to restrict HIV. Here, we show that a novel combination of two double domains can be created that are at least as potent as the most active human A1 proteins. Our study shows that novel combinations of double domain protein combinations are capable of gaining potency and/or escape from antagonism as “super restriction factors”.

Cancer is a disease characterized by unrelenting tissue growth and clonal evolution. During evolution, genetic and epigenetic aberrations provide the reservoir for dysfunctional cellular phenotypes that maintain a tumour’s replicative advantage, while, over time, fluctuating physiological and ecological properties within the microenvironment drive the need for updated adaptations that sustain immortality. However, existing methods used to infer cancer evolution are compressive, slow, or incorrectly specify the underlying cancer evolutionary dynamics. Here, we provide a proof-of-principle synthetic supervised learning method, TumE, that integrates simulated models of cancer development with Bayesian neural networks, and infer ongoing selection in bulk-sequenced single-cell biopsies. This extensible framework provides a foundation and future directions for harnessing progressive computational methods for the benefit of both cancer genomics and, in turn, the cancer patient.

African trypanosomes are parasites mainly transmitted by tsetse flies. In Chad, HAT and animals ( AAT ) are endemic. This study investigates the diversity and distribution of African trypansomes, including the occurrence of potentially zoonotic species in humans and livestock. Besides T. brucei gambiense, which is a parasite of cattle with global distribution, the control had not started in Mandoul, an isolated area bordering the Central African Republic ( CAR ), and Maro, where a control campaign was ongoing. We collected blood from 717 human and 540 cattle blood samples, followed by amplicon sequencing. Our results indicate the need to investigate the infectivity of the unknown try panosome species regarding their potential.

Hybridization is a fascinating evolutionary phenomenon that raises the question of how species maintain their integrity. Inter-species hybridization occurs between certain Schistosoma species that can cause important public health and veterinary issues. Recent genomic evidence indicates that some S. haematobium populations show signatures of genomic introgression. Here, we conducted a genomic comparative study of 19 isolates originating from a wide geographical range over Africa. We developed 56, 181 SNPs from whole genome sequencing to study the genomic relationship between the two parental species, which are associated with humans and animals respectively, and their hybrids. Based on a whole genomic sequencing approach that allowed a clear differentiation of all S. bovis strains, a natural hybrid and an experimentally generated hybrid from Corsica, Mali and Egypt. Together our results highlight the fact that the genome-wide genomic relationships between these two sister species have recently received considerable attention due to their ease of inter-breeding, geographically widespread sympatric transmission, high-prevalences and moreover to the potential zoonotic implications that this hybridizing system suggests.

Human immunodeficiency virus ( HIV ) vaccines have not been successful in clinical trials. Dimeric IgA ( dIgA ) is the most abundant antibody class in mucosal tissues, making it a prime candidate for potential HIV vaccines. We coupled Positron Emission Tomography ( PET ) imaging and fluorescent microscopy of 64Cu-labeled, photoactivatable HIV ( PA-GFP-BaL ) to determine the distribution and localization of HIV virions in the colon two hours after exposure. Our results show that HIV virus and antibodies rapidly disseminate throughout the entire length of the large intestine in an asymmetric manner. Moreover, virion were found in a subset of mesenteric lymph nodes. Taken together, these technologies enable in vivo and in situ visualization of antibody-virus interactions and detailed investigations of early events in HIV infection.

Understanding the relationships between biological processes is paramount to unravel pathophysiological mechanisms. These relationships can be modeled with Transfer Functions ( TFs ), with no need of a priori hypotheses as to the shape of the transfer function. Here we present Iliski, a software dedicated to TF computation between two signals. It includes different pre-treatment routines, deterministic and non-deterministic optimization algorithms that are adapted to disparate datasets, highlighting the software benefits and caveats in the computation and evaluation. We also propose a workflow that will help users to choose the best computation according to their dataset.

Congenital Zika Syndrome ( CZS ), including Zika-induced microcephaly, can affect an infant’s ability to feed and swallow properly, either from the breast or when using cups or bottles. We conducted a qualitative evidence synthesis of the values and preferences of relevant stakeholders ( e. g. pregnant women, mothers, family members and health practitioners ) concerning infant ( 0–2 years ) feeding in the presence of: 1 ) CzS; 2 ) severe disability and nonprogressive, chronic encephalopathies, which present with similar problems. The authors synthesised their findings using thematic synthesis techniques, and confidence in them was assessed using GRADE-CERQual. A further eight indirect studies ( all from Brazil ) reported feeding difficulties in infants and toddlers with severe disabilities. Confidence in most findings ranged from low to moderate. Breast-feeding represented the preference for all mothers in both reviews; the inability to do so affected bonding between parents and child and generated fear and anxiety relating to feeding choices, especially around the risks of choking and swallowing; and a strong desire to achieve individual maternal autonomy in infant feeding decisions. This evidence base has limitations, but consistently reported that parents of children with feeding problems due to congenital abnormalities, or similar, need information, advice and counselling; substantial emotional support. Parents perceive that these needs are often neither recognised nor satisfied; optimal feeding and support strategies for this population have not yet been identified.

Recombinant protein immunogens hold great promise against difficult viral and microbial targets for which there are currently no viable vaccine solutions ( e. g. HIV, malaria ). Well-defined structure, control over the exposure of different epitopes, high sample homogeneity and efficient manufacturing are some of the advantages of this vaccine platform. Two-component, self-assembling nanoparticles represent a versatile platform for multivalent presentation of viral antigens. Env trimers, based on subtype A ( BG505 ) or consensus group M ( ConM ) sequences and engineered with SOSIP stabilizing mutations, were fused to an underlying trimeric building block of each nanoparticle. Initial screening yielded one icosahedral and two tetrahedral candidate, capable of presenting twenty or four copies of a trimer. In a number of analyses, including detailed structural characterization by cryo-EM, demonstrated that the nanopoparticles possessed the intended structural and antigenic properties. When the immunogenicity of conM-SOSIP-T33_dn2A or as soluble proteins were compared in rabbits, the two antibodies elicited similar serum antibody binding titers. Neutralizing antibody levels were slightly elevated in the animals given the virus and were initially more focused to the hemer apex. Altogether, our findings indicate that tetraphenic and co-assembly-based platforms can be successfully applied for presentations of HIV envelope glycoproteins. The optimal implementation to different immunization strategies remains to be determined.

Pseudorabies virus ( PRV ) has evolved various immune evasion mechanisms that target host antiviral immune responses. However, the roles and mechanisms of herpesvirus-encoded tegument proteins targeting cGAS-STING pathways remain largely unclear. In this study, we identified that the proteasome protein UL13 interacts with STING and recruits the E3 ligase RING-finger protein 5 ( RNF5 ) to promote K27-/K29-linked ubiquitination and degradation of StING. Consequently, deficiency of RNR5 enhances the production of type I interferons ( IFNs ) and shows attenuated pathogenicity in mice. Our findings thus identify a new strategy and mechanism to evade the innate immune response via recruitment of a novel protein kinase.

Arthropod-borne viruses ( arboviruses ) require to alternately replicate in hosts with drastically different body temperatures to perpetuate. While vertebrate hosts tend to maintain temperatures of approximately 37°C, arthropods are subject to ambient temperatures which can have a daily fluctuation of > 10° C. Temperatures impact vector competence, extrinsic incubation period, and mosquito survival unimodally, with optimal conditions occurring at some intermediate temperature. In addition, the mean and range of daily temperature fluctuations influence vector replication and dissemination within vectors. Our results support the extensive existing literature [11, 12, 41] that EIT controls infection and transmission within mosquitoes.

Olfactory integration is important for survival in a natural habitat. However, how the nervous system processes signals of two odorants present simultaneously to generate a coherent behavioral response is poorly understood. Here, we characterize circuit basis for a form of olfaction in Caenorhabditis elegans. We find that the presence of a repulsive odorant, 2-nonanone, that signals threat strongly blocks the attraction of other odants, such as isoamyl alcohol ( IAA ) or benzaldehyde, to signal food. Loss of these genes mildly reduces the response to the repellent, and disrupts the integration effect. Restoring the function of OSM-5 in either AWB or ASH, two sensory neurons known to mediate the avoidance effect of the odorantly-evoked avoidance, is sufficient to rescue. Our results identify redundant neural circuits and uncover the neuronal and cellular basis of this complex odoractory task.

Schistosomiasis is a neglected tropical disease that affects 230–250 million people annually, mainly in poor communities. Parasite’s egg-antigens manipulate the immune system, making them probable next-generation vaccines. In the present study, we evaluated, for the first time, the immunizing efficacy of Schisto mansoni eggs-derived EVs against murine schistiasis. Results showed significant reduction of tegumentally deranged adult worms, hepatic and intestinal egg counts reduction by 46. 58% and 93. 17% respectively, accompanied by remarkable amelioration of sizes, numbers and histopathology of egg granulomata mediated by high interferon gamma ( IFN γ ) and antibody level. Using sera from vaccinated mice, our results revealed two bands of ~ 14 KDa and ~ 21 kDa, proving that EVs are able to stimulate specific antibodies response.

Mycetoma is considered a neglected tropical disease globally. However, data on its burden and the associated complications in Uganda are limited. This study aimed to retrospectively estimate the burden of the disease by reviewing biopsy reports at the Pathology reference laboratory, Makerere University, Kampala, Uganda, together with a systematic review of published literature. The study limitation includes the fact that cases were found by searching archives from a single hospital in only one city. There was a general decline in the number of cases detected recently, highlighting that it is a rare disease. Further studies are merited, including active community-based case findings.

Malaria is one of the most prevalent vector-borne diseases around the world. The aim of Malaysia to eliminate malaria nationwide by 2020 seems need to be prolonged. In order to assess the infection risk and properly manage the malaria elimination programme, several epidemiological studies of Plasmodium in simian host species have been carried out. This systematic review was conducted according to the PRISMA guidelines to select appropriate articles as references. Data searches were performed through international databases such as Google Scholar, PubMed, CrossRef, Scopus, Web of Science and Science Direct for original articles published from 2000 until 2021. All published studies were conducted in Peninsular Malaysia ( 5/7; 71% ) followed by East Malaysia. Most studies showed positive detection of P. cynomolgi in macaques and the highest prevalence of malaria parasite in the macaque population. These findings are important for public health management.

Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) infection is strongly associated with several malignancies, including B-cell lymphomas and epithelial tumors. EBNA1 is a key antigen expressed during latency that is required for maintenance of the viral episome DNA replication and the regulation of viral gene transcription. However, the mechanism utilized by the virus to maintain latent infection at the levels of posttranslational regulation remains largely unclear. In this study, we demonstrate that the SUMO-interacting motifs ( SIM2 and SIM3 ), and mutation of SIM1, but notSIM3, dramatically disrupts the dimerization, while the EBNASIM motif contributes to the polySUMO2 modification. This study provides a potential therapeutic specific target for the development of anti-EBV-associated cancers.

Grain yield can be partitioned into several yield components with higher heritability. Among these traits, spikelet number per spike ( SNS ) is established early in the reproductive phase when the terminal spikelets are formed, limiting the effect of environmental conditions after this point. In this study, we established that the A-genome homeolog of WHEAT ORTHOLOG OF APO1 ( WAPO-A1 ) was a leading candidate gene for this QTL. Loss-of-function mutants of wapo-a1 showed reduced sNS in tetraploid wheat, and this effect was exacerbated in transgenic wheat plants carrying extra copies of this gene. By contrast, the H2 haplotype is associated with the strongest effects in increasing SSS and GNS. Field experiments also showed that this region is important to improve grain yield.

Scrub typhus is a zoonotic disease caused by bacteria of the genus Orientia and transmitted by trombiculid mites, called chiggers. The disease mainly occurs within a region of Asia-Pacific called the tsutsugamushi triangle, where rodents are known as the most relevant hosts for the vector. However, the reservoir ( s ) and vector are unknown. In this study, rodents were live-trapped in six sites and examined for chigger infestation. All study sites were rural areas on Chiloé Island in southern Chile, previously identified as probable localities where human cases acquired the disease. During a total of 4, 713 trap-nights, 244 rodents of seven species were captured: Abrothrix olivacea. Chigger mite pools were detected on all seven rodent species with a 55% prevalence rate, which varied according to site specific host abundance. Herpetacarus and two other genera were found with high infesting rates of rodents in sites previously associated with probable exposure of scrub typhiases in South America. A substantial percentage ( 93% ) were positive for orientia DNA, suggesting that the rodents serve as vectors and reservoirs of this emerging disease in Chile.

During the 2015–2017 Zika epidemic, dengue and chikungunya–two other viral diseases with the same vector as Zika–were also in circulation. Clinical presentation of these diseases can vary from person to person in terms of symptoms and severity, making it difficult to differentially diagnose them. Given the importance of surveillance data for informing epidemiological analyses, our aim was to quantify the potential extent of misdiagnosis during this epidemic. We generated revised estimates of reported cases of Zika that accounted for the accuracy of diagnoses made on the basis of clinical presentation with or without laboratory confirmation. Applying this method to weekly reported case data from 43 countries throughout Latin America and the Caribbean, we estimated that 944, 700 Zika cases occurred when assuming all confirmed cases were diagnosed using molecular methods versus 608, 400 ( 95% CrI: 442, 000–821, 800 ) cases that occurred with serological methods. Our results imply that mis Diagnosis was more common in countries with proportionally higher reported Zika infections, such as Brazil, than in other co-circulating diseases that appear likely to cocirculate in the Americas and elsewhere for years to come.

HBV is an enveloped DNA virus that replicates its DNA genome via reverse transcription of a pregenomic ( pg ) RNA intermediate in hepatocytes. Interestingly, HBV RNA can be detected in virus-like particles in chronic hepatitis B ( CHB ) patient serum and has been utilized as a biomarker for intrahepatic cccDNA activity in treated patients. However, the biogenesis and molecular characteristics of serum HBVs RNA remain to be fully defined. In this study, we found that the encapsidated HCV pgRNA-containing nonenveloped capsids are detergent- and ribonuclease-resistant. Furthermore, our study provides new insights into a better understanding of the cellular ESCRT-dependent MVB secretory pathway for egress, in a similar way as DNA-virion morphogenesis.

Tuberculosis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis is a significant public health concern, exacerbated by the emergence of drug-resistant TB. To combat the host’s dynamic environment, Mtb encodes multiple DNA repair enzymes that play a critical role in maintaining genomic integrity. We hypothesized that deletion of DNA base excision repair genes may help bacteria in better adaptability under stress conditions. The uracil DNA glycosylases ( ung and udgB ) initiate the repair; hence we investigated the biological impact of deleting UDGs in the adaptation of pathogen. The biological master clock, suprachiasmatic nucleus ( of rat and mouse ), is composed of ~10, 000 clock cells which are heterogeneous with respect to their circadian periods. Despite this inhomogeneity, an intact SCN maintains a very good degree of circadian phase ( time ) coherence which is vital for sustaining various circadian rhythmic activities, and it is supposedly achieved by not just one but a few different cell-to-cell coupling mechanisms, among which action potential ( AP ) -mediated connectivity is known to be essential. But, due to technical difficulties and limitations in experiments, so far very little information is available about the morphology of the connectivity at a cellular scale. Building upon this limited amount of information, here we exhaustively and systematically explore a large pool of various network morphologies to come up with some plausible network features. All candidates under consideration reflect an experimentally obtained ‘indegree distribution’ as well as a physical range distribution of afferent clock cell connections all together. The successful, realistic networks have several common features: 1 ) their clustering coefficients Cs are very small and there are no “hubs” ( i. e., the degree distribution has no fat tail ) ; 2 ) the number of intra-core edges is about 7. 5 times greater than that inside the shell; and 3 ) all dynamic properties of ( perturbed ) and autonomous ) circadian waves are consistent with the picture of a well modularized subregions ( core and shell ).

To characterize the functional role of the left-ventral occipito-temporal cortex ( lvOT ) during reading in a quantitatively explicit and testable manner, we propose the lexical categorization model ( LCM ). This model assumes that luvOT optimizes linguistic processing by allowing fast meaning access when words are familiar and filtering out orthographic strings without meaning. In a second evaluation, using functional brain imaging described in the literature we empirically demonstrate that this model can simulate multiple published fMRI findings that have been viewed as contradictory, and it does so better than competing models.

The circadian clock exerts significance influence on the immune system and disruption of circadian rhythms has been linked to inflammatory pathologies. Shift workers often experience circadian misalignment as their irregular work schedules disrupt the natural light-dark cycle, which in turn can cause serious health problems. In particular, shift work is associated with impairment in immune function, and those alterations are sex-specific. The goal of this study is to better understand the mechanisms that explain the weakened immune response in shift workers. To achieve that goal, we have constructed a mathematical model of the mammalian pulmonary circadian system coupled to an acute inflammation model in the male and female rats. Our model predicts that a host is more sensitive to lipopolysaccharide at circadian time ( CT ) CT12 versus CT0 due to a dynamic change of Interleukin 10 ( IL-10 ), an anti-inflammatory cytokine. This model can serve as an essential component in an integrative model that will yield mechanistic understanding of how shift-work-mediated circadian disruptions affect the inflammatory and other physiological responses.

Rapid urbanization, global trade, and the exceptionally great numbers of worldwide visitors during Hajj and Umrah have all placed the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia at a significant risk of introducing several vector-borne tropical diseases, such as dengue fever virus ( DENV ) infection. In this study, we estimated the global economic burden of the disease over the period 2013–2017, by processing national data including all declared cases recorded in referral centers in the western region, being the endemic region. We observed highest estimated costs in 2016 with over US$168. 5 Million total costs, including direct costs and indirect costs for a total 4415 confirmed cases. Our findings highlight the urgent need for an effective national prevention strategy to perform considerable cost-savings besides reducing morbidity.

Fat stored in the form of lipid droplets has long been considered a defining characteristic of cytoplasm. However, recent studies have shown that nuclear lipids occur in multiple cells and tissues, including in human patients with fatty liver disease. The function ( s ) of stored fat in nuclei has not been determined, and it may instead be deleterious by disrupting nuclear organization or triggering aggregation of hydrophobic proteins. In this study, we show that a large volume of a meiotic germ nucleus can be filled with fat without triggering apoptosis and that embryos derived from such germ cells are viable and healthy.

Streptococcus pneumoniae is the main cause of bacterial meningitis worldwide. Despite access to antibiotics and intensive care, around 50% of the survivors suffer from permanent neurological damages, sequelae, after the infection has resolved. Little is known about how pneumococci interact with and damage neurons leading to neuronal cell death. Here, we investigated the mechanisms of interaction with neurons. We found that the pilus-1 adhesin RrgA and the cytotoxin pneumolysin ( Ply ) co-localize with neuronal β-actin, thereby promoting adhesion and invasion of neurons, and neuronal death, possibly due to increased intracellular Ca2+ levels depending on presence of Ply, as well as on actin cytoskeleton disassembly. Using purified proteins we show that Ply interacts with the neuronal plasma membrane, thus increasing the exposure on the outer surface of β filaments, which leads to more binding sites available for PIgR and PECAM binding. Furthermore, the neurotoxic effect could be blocked using anti-β-actsin antibodies. The generated data potentially helps explaining mechanisms for why bacterial pathogens frequently cause neurological diseases.

Aggression is ubiquitous in animals because it may increase an individual’s chance to survive and to transmit its genes to the next generation. However, how such mutual assessments are carried out at the molecular level during fighting remains unknown. Using the fighting fish Betta splendens, we studied behavioral and brain-transcriptomic changes during the fight between the two opponents. At the behavioral level, surface-breathing, biting/striking occurred only during intervals between mouth-locking. Eventually, the behaviors were synchronized, with each pair showing a unique behavioral pattern. We examined the expression patterns of 23, 306 brain transcripts using RNA-sequencing data from brains of fighting pairs after a 20-min ( D20 ) and a 60-minute fight. The two competitors in each D60 fighting pair showed a strong gene expression correlation. Moreover, each fighting pairing showed pair-specific individualization in a grade of membership analysis ( GoM ), and were grouped as a pair in the heatmap clustering. Our findings suggest that this synchronization provides a physiological basis for the behavior synchronization.

Mosquito viruses cause unpredictable outbreaks of disease. Recently, several unassigned viruses isolated from mosquitoes, including the Omono River virus ( OmRV ), were identified as totivirus-like viruses, with features similar to those of the Totiviridae family. However, most reported members of this family infect fungi or protozoans and lack an extracellular life cycle stage. Here, we identified a new strain of Om RV and determined high-resolution structures for this virus using single-particle cryo-electron microscopy. The structures feature an unexpected protrusion at the five-fold vertex, which could result in several conformational changes in the major capsid. All these structures, together with some biological results, suggest the protrusions’ associations with the intracellular transmission.

mTOR, a serine/threonine protein kinase that is involved in a series of critical cellular processes, can be found in two functionally distinct complexes, mTORC1 and m TORC2. In contrast, little is known about the mechanisms that regulate this complex. Here we show that the expression of the non-canonical guanine nucleotide exchange factor ( GEF ) for heterotrimeric Gαs/olf type subunits, Ric-8B, is reduced in mice that are not viable and that die early during embryogenesis ( between E4 and E8. 5 ). Interestingly, this analysis also revealed an unexpected impairment of a signaling pathway involving GPCRs and G proteins. Phosphorylation of Akt at Ser473 is downregulated in the mutant embryos, indicating a decreased activity of MTOR. Our results reveal a crucial role for the conserved protein in development and provide novel insights into the signaling pathways that control the protein.

Dengue fever remains challenging to predict due to large variations in epidemic size across seasons driven by a number of factors including population susceptibility, mosquito density, meteorological conditions, geographical factors, and human mobility. An ensemble forecast system is first proposed that addresses the difficulty of predicting outbreaks with drastically different scales. We validated the forecasting system in Guangzhou, China during the 2011–2012 to 2017–2018 seasons.

Leprosy and leprosy-related stigma can have a major impact on psychosocial wellbeing of persons affected and their family members. Resilience is a process that incorporates many of the core skills and abilities which may enable people to address stigma and discrimination. However, most of them are highly resource intensive, with even the brief interventions requiring multiple counselling sessions with each family over many months. We used a quasi-experimental, before-after study design with a mixed methods approach. The 10-week family-based intervention was designed to strengthen the resilience of individuals and families by enhancing their protective abilities and capacity to overcome adversity. In addition, semi-structured interviews were conducted post-intervention. Data were collected at baseline, a few weeks after the intervention, and in the Odisha cohort again at six months after completion. Qualitative data were thematically analysed. Overall, all participants described drawing benefit from the programme. Participants especially appreciated the social dimensions of it. A large-scale efficacy trial is necessary to determine the effectiveness and long-term sustainability of this intervention.

Bioriented attachment of sister chromatids to the mitotic spindle is essential for chromosome segregation. In budding yeast, the conserved protein shugoshin ( Sgo1 ) contributes to this process by recruiting the protein phosphatase PP2A-Rts1 and the condensin complex to centromeres. Using peptide prints, we identified a Serine-Rich Motif ( SRM ) that mediates the interaction with the centromeric region. We show that the interactions are regulated via phosphorylation within the SRm and we determined the phospho-sites using mass spectrometry. Our findings identify novel mechanisms that control the activity of the ShUGOSHIN protein at the pericentromere.

T cell epitope candidates are commonly identified using computational prediction tools in order to enable applications such as vaccine design, cancer neoantigen identification, development of diagnostics and removal of unwanted immune responses against protein therapeutics. The ability of currently available tools to predict T cell candidate epitopes has not been comprehensively evaluated. In this study, we used a recently published dataset that systematically defined the major peptides recognized in vaccinia virus ( VACV ) infected C57BL/6 mice ( expressing H-2Db and H2Kb ), considering both peptide predicted to bind MHC or experimentally eluted from infected cells. Impressively, these methods were able to capture more than half of all currently publicly available predictions within the N = 767, 788 predictions made for different lengths of relevant lengths. These performance metrics provide guidance for immunologists as to which prediction methods to use, and what success rates are possible for these predictions when considering a highly controlled system of administered immunizations to inbred mice.

Genome-wide association studies in humans have shown that environmental and acquired phenotypes, including smoking, ageing and obesity, are associated with altered DNA methylation in peripheral blood. Whether such associations could be mediated by epigenetic changes in spermatozoa that influence the development and physiology of a man’s offspring in utero has generated considerable interest in recent years. Studies in non-human mammals suggest that such association could also be influenced by factors such as dietary alterations, toxicants and even psychological stress, although the majority of these results have yet to be replicated independently. In this study, we used the Illumina MethylationEPIC array in a cross-sectional study of matched samples of human blood and sperm from lean ( n = 47; replication ) and overweight/obese males to identify obesity-associated methylomic signatures. We found that the levels of methylated DNA in blood are highly discordant, and methylate levels are correlated at only a minority of CpG sites ( ~1% ). When compared to a wide range of somatic tissue samples available on the Gene Expression Omnibus ( GEO ) data repository, our analyses provide a unique insight into the intergenerational effects of paternal obesity and whether whole blood can be used as a surrogate tissue for analyses of genetic traits.

Neurotropic reovirus infects the central nervous system ( CNS ) to cause lethal encephalitis in newborn animals. In this study, we used primary neuron cultures in combination with small-molecule inhibitors of endocytosis to determine mechanisms of neuronal entry and transport in neurons. We discovered that the cellular machinery mediating macropinocytic uptake is required for the entry of the virus. This mechanism differs from clathrin-mediated intracellular transport, which is used by neurotropic viruses to invade non-neuronal cells. Our results establish a foundation for further exploration of common host factors co-opted by pathogens for neural invasion. Furthermore, our findings emphasize consideration of cell type-specific entry mechanisms in the tailored design of neuroinvasive viruses.

Malaria continues to be a major global health priority with an estimated 229 million cases and 409, 000 deaths in 2019. Increased resistance to antimalarial drugs has heightened concerns as widely used drugs like artemisinin, which is commonly used to combat chloroquine resistance, is increasingly failing. The development of an effective vaccine against malaria has been prioritized. RTS, S/AS01 is the first, and to date, the only vaccine that has demonstrated significant reduction of clinical and severe malaria in endemic cohorts in Phase 3 trials. Although the vaccine is protective, efficacy declines over time with kinetics paralleling the decline in antibody responses to the Pf circumsporozoite protein ( PfCSP ). Here, we characterized and characterized seven monoclonal antibodies to C-terminal domain of CSP ( ctC SP ) from volunteers immunized with R TS, s/as01. Competition and crystal structure studies indicated that the antibodies target two different sites on opposite faces of ccSP. One site contains a polymorphic region ( denoted α-ctCsp ) and has previously been previously characterized, whereas the second is a previously undescribed site on the conserved β-sheet face. Antibodies to both sites exhibited broad reactivity with a diverse panel of peptides whose sequences were derived from field isolates of P. falciparum. These findings suggest that a novel epitope on C SP could be targeted by prophylactic antibodies and exploited in structure-based vaccine design.

The obligate intracellular parasite Toxoplasma gondii infects a wide range of warm-blooded animals and is highly prevalent in humans. This parasite imposes a significant risk to patients with a compromised immune system and to pregnant woman. The regulatory role of lysine malonylation in many biological processes has been established in various organisms. However, this type of protein post-translational modification ( PTM ) remains poorly understood, with only one study having investigated its expression pattern in one strain. In this study, we profiled the level of variation in the virulence and repertoire of differentially expressed proteins in T. gonds using quantitative liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry ( LC-MS/MS ) and immuno-affinity purification. Our analysis was performed on three distinct strains with distinctive pathogenicity in mice, including RH strain ( type I ), PRU strain, and VEG strain; 50 proteins and 59 sites were upregulated, 50 protein and 53 sites was downregulated. Differentially mallated proteins were involved in key processes, such as those mediating the regulation of proteins metabolism, stress response, glycolysis, actin cytoskeleton. These results provide a new resource for elucidating how the contribution of the LYSINE MALONYLATION modification contributes to the genotype-related differences in energy metabolism.

Nematode parasites infect approximately 1. 5 billion people globally and are a significant public health concern. There is an accepted need for new, more effective anthelmintic drugs. Nicotinic acetylcholine receptors on parasite nerve and somatic muscle are targets of the cholinomimetic anthermintics, while glutamate-gated chloride channels in the pharynx are affected by the avermectins. Here we describe a novel nicotininic receptor that is a potential new drug target. This receptor is comprised of five non-Î± EAT-2 subunits and is not sensitive to existing cholinesterase inhibitors. We found that the functional expression of this subunit protein is dependent on co-expression with the mature receptor, and different homologs alter the pharmacological properties. Thus we have described not only a new potential drug receptor but also new type of obligate auxiliary protein for nAChRs.

The pathogenesis of HIV-1 infection results in the destruction of CD4 T lymphocytes, the onset of AIDS and death from opportunistic infections. CXCR4-using viruses are considered more pathogenic than R5-viruses, and their proportion increases as infection progresses. However, counterexamples to this paradigm are common, suggesting heterogeneity in virus virulence. Here, we investigated the role of a chemokine receptor, CxCL12, as a driving force in evolution of the phenotypic properties of these viruses. We found that viruses resistant ( RES ) are frequent in patients with a severe drop in peripheral blood CD 4TL levels, most often late in infection, only rarely at the time of primary infection. RES viruses adopt a more closed conformation with distinct antigenicity, which mirrors their situation in lymphoid organs and to deplete bystander activated effector memory cells. This work improves our understanding of virus pathophysiology and the transmission of infection and suggests that RES virus’ receptors could represent new therapeutic targets to help prevent CD6TL depletion in HIV+ patients on cART.

Zoonotic cutaneous leishmaniasis ( ZCL ) is endemic in Palestine and transmitted by Phlebotomus sand flies. They inhabit dens of hyraxes, the reservoir animal. Control measures were implemented since 1996 but cases still occur. During July-September 2019, we conducted a 12-week controlled interrupted time series study in two control and one intervention sites. We measured weekly and 36hrs post-intervention sand fly abundance inside dens using CDC light traps using Next-Generation Sequencing to identify the Leishmania species and the prevalence of infection in these vectors. Our results showed that the application of insecticide thermal fogging inside hyrax dens reduced the abundance of sandfly vectors at the “source of disease” space. In the first two weeks of the intervention period, sand Fly abundance decreased by 65% ( IRR: 0. 35, 95%CI: 1. 11–0. 57 ) at two and five weeks and 82% for the complete period ( zero infections until week two ). The proportion of P. sergenti that was infected with L. tropica in the early part of this period was 14% and 3. 9%, respectively, suggesting it could be an effective source-reduction measure for vector control.

Foot-and-mouth disease ( FMDV ) is a highly contagious disease of cloven-hooved animals affecting most notably cattle, pigs, sheep and goats. The 5′ untranslated region ( UTR ) of Foot-And-Mouth disease virus is considerably longer than in other viruses from the picornavirus family and consists of a number of distinctive structural motifs that includes multiple ( 2, 3 or 4 depending on the virus strain ) putative PKs linked in tandem. In particular, pseudoknot ( PK ) structures, which are present in a wide range of RNA molecules, have a variety of roles. Here, using bioinformatics, sub-genomic replicons and recombinant viruses, we have investigated the structural conservation and importance of the PNPs in the viral lifecycle. Our results show that despite a replicon lacking any PK structures retaining the ability to replicate, viruses completely lacking PK were not viable and at least one PK was essential for recovery of infections virus, suggesting a role for the PK in virion assembly.

Praziquantel ( PZQ ) is currently the only recommended drug for infection and disease caused by the schistosome species that infects humans; however, the current tablet formulation is not suitable for pre-school age children mainly due to its bitterness and the large tablet size. In this study, we assessed the palatability of two new orally disintegrating tablet ( ODT ) formulations of PzQ in children aged 6–11 years old, with or without infection as this was not part of the assessment. The children were stratified according to age group and gender, then randomized to receive each formulation in a Pre-specified sequence. Over 2 days, children took part in the oDT assessment and were evaluated using a 100 mm visual analogue scale ( VAS ) incorporating a 5-point hedonic scale, immediately after spitting out the test product and after 2–5 minutes ( VASt = 0 primary outcome ). No serious adverse events were reported. This study provides evidence for the newly formulated formulation to allow the inclusion of this group in MDA campaigns and in treatment as well.

Herpesviruses are a leading cause of birth defects and transplant failures. There are no effective drugs for CMV without significant toxicities ( especially during pregnancy, with high risk to the fetus ), and resistance to existing anti-CMV drugs is widespread. As part of an effort to provide a treatment that avoids the possibility of drug resistance, we discovered a novel mechanism of action ( MOA ) and specific compounds to treat all nine human herpesvirus as well as other viral infections with genome-pressure-dependent replication. This work serves as a proof-of-concept to demonstrate the feasibility of a new antiviral target—suppressing pressure-driven viral genome ejection—that is likely impervious to developing resistance.

Lymphatic filariasis ( LF ) is endemic in 72 countries where about 1. 39 billion people are at the risk of acquiring infection. Wuchereria bancrofti is the predominant parasite while Brugia malayi and B. timori are restricted in distribution. Transmission control with mass drug administration ( MDA ) ( with an option of supplementing integrated vector management ) and alleviation of sufferings of the diseased with morbidity management and disability prevention ( MMDP ) are the recommended strategies for achieving the goal of LF elimination. Recently, molecular xenomonitoring ( MX ) has been demonstrated to be a potential surveillance tool to supplement TAS for different parasite and vector combinations. In 2004, India, contributing around 44. 3% of global burden, launched the National programme to eliminate LF in 256 endemic districts in 21 States and Union Territories with about 610 million people at risk. MLCs could be the choice, for now, to sample Ae. niveus mosquitoes. The vector-parasite MX, can be used to evaluate interventions in this area after further standardization of protocol.

CREB-binding protein ( CBP ) is an evolutionarily conserved post-translational modification ( PTM ) of proteins, which has recently attracted much attention due to its broad-spectrum and essential roles in regulating cellular functions, such as proliferation, cell cycle, differentiation, apoptosis and DNA damage responses. Despite closely related features in structure and function, the acetyltransferase activity of CBPs remains largely unexplored. Here, we found that cellular USP12 interacts with the HAT domain of CREB binding protein and inhibits the activation of interferon ( IFN ) antiviral signaling independently of its deubiquitinases activity. Furthermore, our study uncovers a cell-intrinsic regulation of the strength of CDP’s activity in the cytoplasm.

The International Committee on the Taxonomy of Viruses currently lists >180 viruses in the genus Orthobunyavirales. Melao virus ( MELV ) was first isolated from Aedes and Psorophora spp. mosquitoes captured in Melajo forest in Trinidad, and this virus has been identified in horses and humans, suggesting that it can cause infections leading to antibody production in these hosts. In contrast, Oropouche virus causes meningoencephalitis, which is presently one of the most common arbovirus-associated febrile illnesses in Brazil. Heretofore not described as a human pathogen, OROV RNA was detected in plasma of an additional child, using an unbiased sequencing approach, with phylogenetic inference suggesting a close relationship with strains from Brazil in 2014. Abdominal pain was reported by four case patients with the disease in two cases. Our findings document the occurrence of these viruses within the Caribbean region and highlight the critical importance of surveillance with viral genome sequence analyses to identify outbreaks caused by these and other emerging viruses.

COVID-19, caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome-associated coronavirus 2 ( SARS-CoV-2 ), has had significant economic impacts in countries affected by the disease outbreak in 2019–2020. Due to the high immunogenic of S protein, it could be a potential target for S-protein-based vaccine development. The spike protein of the viral protein is responsible for the processes of virus attachment to host receptor angiotensin-converting enzyme 2, cell entry, and virus-cell membrane fusion to release viral RNA into host cells. In this study, we report a DNA vaccine containing the spike gene for delivery via electroporation. We found that this vaccine could induce neutralizing antibody and Th1-biased immune responses. Furthermore, hamsters immunized with this technique generated protective immunity against the S2-mediated challenge in vivo.

Lymphatic filariasis ( LF ), a neglected tropical disease, causes permanent disability through chronic manifestations of lymphedema, elephantiasis and hydrocele accounting for 1. 36 million disability adjusted life years. Globally more than 858 million people living in 49 endemic countries face the risk of infection. Disease control programs have mostly targeted the interruption of LF transmission through mass drug administration ( MDA ) whilst placing less emphasis on promoting morbidity management and disability prevention services ( MMDP ) for those presenting with chronic forms of the disease. In Luangwa District, Zambia, LF is a public health concern, as 87 of 118 districts are considered endemic. LF patients opted to visit traditional healers before going to health facilities. Hydrocele patients were afraid of hydrocelectomies as they were thought to cause infertility or death. Very few community members were able to identify any home and facility-based care strategies for lymphoedema. Health system and cultural barriers to seeking healthcare included; long distances to the health facility, lack of awareness of existing MDP services, gender and social norms, and fear of stigmatization. Community members who viewed LF as a disease that arose due to witchcraft rather than mosquitoes were more likely to seek help from traditional healer and homecare strategies.

The Human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 ( HTLV-1 ) orf I-encoded accessory protein p8 is cleaved from its precursor p12, and both proteins contribute to viral persistence. P8 induces cellular protrusions, which are thought to facilitate transfer of the protein to target cells and virus transmission. Here, we report that vasodilator-stimulated phosphoprotein ( VASP ) promotes actin filament elongation and is a novel interaction partner of p 8 and important for p-8 and H1-associated myelopathy/tropical spastic paraparesis ( HAM/TSP ). Our study revealed that the EVH1 domain is necessary, but not sufficient, for the interaction with the vase-rich protein. We also identified areas of partial co-localization of VasP with p9 at the plasma membrane and in protrusive structures. These findings suggest that a putative interaction partners of vases-p8 could favor the transmission of virus to other cells in an immune competent host.

Sensory deprivation has long been known to cause hallucinations or “phantom” sensations, the most common of which is tinnitus, affecting 10–20% of the population. An observable hearing loss, causing auditory sensory deprivation over a band of frequencies, is present in over 90%. Existing plasticity-based computational models for tinitus are usually driven by homeostatic mechanisms, modeled to fit phenomenological findings. Here, we use an objective-driven learning algorithm to model an early auditory processing neuronal network, e. g., in the dorsal cochlear nucleus. We show that the connectivity patterns and responses learned by the model display several hallmarks of auditory neuronal networks. Specifically, attenuation of peripheral inputs drives the recurrent network towards its critical point and transition into a tnitus-like state. In this state, auditory neurons with similar preferred orientations tend to excite one another, while the network activity resembles responses to genuine inputs, thus, eliciting hallucinations. These findings demonstrate how the mechanisms that normally act to optimize the neural network’s input representation can also elicit pathologies such as auditory deprivation.

Porcine hemagglutinating encephalomyelitis virus ( PHEV ) is a highly neurotropic coronavirus, which is transmitted primarily through respiratory droplets and close contact, entering the central nervous system ( CNS ) from the peripheral nerves at the site of initial infection. However, the neuroinvasion route of the virus is poorly understood. Here, we found that BALB/c mice are susceptible to intranasal infection and showed distinct neurological manifestations. The behavioral study and histopathological examination revealed that phEV attacks neurons in the CNS and causes significant smell and taste dysfunction in mice. Furthermore, viral replication in olfactory system and CNS is associated with inflammatory and immune responses, tissue disorganization, and dysfunction. Overall, our findings suggest a nonstochastic pathway of neural transmutation.

Glucose is an essential energy substance in animals and humans, which directly or indirectly produces energy for metabolic processes. Some tissues, such as the brain and red blood cells in mammals, rely on glucose to meet their energy requirements. Glycometabolism homeostasis maintains the blood glucose levels, but the molecular mechanisms by which organisms regulate the glucose metabolism from a feeding state switching to a non-feeding state are not fully understood. Using the holometabolous lepidopteran insect Helicoverpa armigera, cotton bollworm, as a model, we revealed that the steroid hormone 20-hydroxyecdysone ( 20E ) upregulated the expression of transcription factor Krüppel-like factor ( Klf15 ) in the fat body during metamorphosis. Knockdown of KLF15 using RNA interference delayed pupation and repressed autophagy and apoptosis of larval fat-body during larva-to-adult transition. We also showed that 20 E, via its nuclear receptor EcR, upregulates the transcription of the gene Atg8, a transcriptional regulator involved in gluconeogenesis, trehalose and glycogen synthesis. The expression profiles of kinetics and transcription factors were examined to analyze their function in development.

The SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus has emerged as the most challenging global health crisis within a century. Vaccination is a promising strategy to end the pandemic. As for other enveloped viruses, the primary vaccine target is the trimeric spike ( S ) protein on the envelope of S. S mediates viral entry into the target cell. In this study, we performed molecular dynamics simulations of a 4. 1 million atom system containing a patch of viral membrane with four full-length, fully glycosylated and palmitoylated S proteins. By mapping steric accessibility, structural rigidity, sequence conservation, and generic antibody binding signatures we recover known epitopes on S and reveal promising epitope candidates for structure-based vaccine design. We find that the extensive and inherently flexible glycan coat shields a surface area larger than expected from static structures, highlighting the importance of structural dynamics. Our computational approach is general and can be extended to other viral envelope proteins whose structures have been characterized.

Type I interferons ( IFNs ) are major antiviral cytokines and their finely tuned production is critical for host protection against viruses. In vitro studies demonstrated that SARS-CoV-2 was very sensitive to type I IFN production and development of severe COVID-19, further promoting the evaluation of the use of recombinant type II interfons as therapeutics. However, the timing of type III IFNF-α treatment was not the sole difference between these trials, as the patients treated in the SOLIDARITY clinical trial were on average at a more severe stage of infection. Our findings support the hypothesis that type 1 IFNA treatment may only be beneficial in patients with low viral load or with mild symptoms at the early stages of disease, while it likely does not provide any benefit in those requiring hospitalization.

Schistosomiasis is a neglected tropical disease caused by blood trematodes of the genus S. haematobium. It is the second most endemic parasitic disease in the world after malaria. The disease has been reported in over 78 countries and is endemic in 52 countries with moderate to high transmission. Despite efforts that have been made over many years, the number of people affected by the disease is not significantly decreased. MALDI-TOF MS ( Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometry ) has revolutionised clinical microbiology by allowing the rapid and accurate classification of many microorganisms ( parasite, fungi and bacteria ). This study aims to assess the efficiency of this proteomic tool for the identification of frozen and ethanol-stored freshwater snails using protein extracts from different body parts. A total of 530 field specimens belonging to nine species ( Biomphalaria pfeifferi, Bulinus forskalii, Buinus senegalensis, B. truncatus, Bellamya unicolor, Cleopatra bulimoides, Lymnaea natalensis and Melanoides tuberculata ) and 89 laboratory-reared specimens, including three species, were used for this study. In a second step, we demonstrated that this tool could also be used to identify ethanol and frozen snail species using proteins extracted from the foot using a specific database of ethanol preserved specimens.

Food and water-borne illness caused by ingestion of ( oo ) cysts of Cryptosporidium and Giardia is one of the major health problems globally. Several methods are available for the detection of microscopic to sub‒microscopic specimens and parasites. Most of these methods require a good laboratory facility and well-trained manpower and are therefore costly. There is a need of affordable and reliable method that can be easily implemented in resource limited settings. In this work, we developed a smartphone based microscopic assay method to screen and quantify ( Oo, cyst ) in vegetable and river water samples. The method consisting of a ball lens of 1 mm diameter, white LED as illumination source and Lugols's iodine staining provided magnification and contrast capable of distinguishing and distinguishing the cyt. We tested the method by spike recovery experiments on vegetable, carrot, cucumber, radish, tomatoes, water, and vegetable samples and showed comparable performance with data obtained using commercial brightfield and fluorescence microscope methods.

Echinococcosis is a zoonotic parasitic disease caused by larval stages of cestodes belonging to the genus Echinococcus. The infection affects people’s health and safety as well as agropastoral sector in western China. In China, the prevalence status and spatial distribution of the disease are not well assessed yet in terms of accurate spatial distributions, patterns, and clusters which are of capital importance in public health for effective disease control strategies implementation. This work was conducted in order to prioritize and optimize control actions against human echinocytosis in the Chinese population by the end of 2018.

Network-based intervention strategies can be effective and cost-efficient approaches to curtailing harmful contagions in myriad settings. As studied, these strategies are often impractical to implement, as they typically assume complete knowledge of the network structure, which is unusual in practice. In this paper, we investigate how different immunization strategies perform under realistic conditions—where the strategies have been informed by partially-observed network data. Our results suggest that global and stochastic approaches are optimal in most cases; the exception is at very high levels of missing data, where they begin to outstrip them in minimizing outbreaks. These results highlight the risks of considering networks as idealized mathematical objects and foregoing the rewards of additional inquiry.

Extracellular recording is an accessible technique used in animals and humans to study the brain physiology and pathology. As the number of recording channels and their density grows it is natural to ask how much improvement the additional channels bring in and how we can optimally use the new capabilities for monitoring the human brain. Here we show that for any given distribution of electrodes we are able to establish exactly what information about current sources in the brains can be recovered and what is strictly unobservable. We demonstrate this in a general setting of previously proposed kernel Current Source Density method and illustrate it with simplified examples as well as using evoked potentials from the barrel cortex obtained with a Neuropixels probe and with compatible model data.

Co-infection of the four major species of human malaria parasite Plasmodium falciparum ( Pf ), P. vivax ( Pv ) ( Pm ) and P. ovale sp. ( Po ) is regularly observed, but there is limited understanding of between-species interactions. We developed molecular diagnostics for detecting asexual and gametocyte stages of Pf, Pv, and Po. These assays were implemented in a unique epidemiological setting in Papua New Guinea with sympatric transmission of all four species permitting a comprehensive investigation of species interactions, for which no assay is published to date.

Many recent studies have revealed that epigenetic abnormalities, particularly aberrant changes in methylation, exert an important causative effect on complex diseases. However, the principal genes that control the pathogenesis of diseases have not yet been identified and the underlying mechanisms of causal genes on diseases remain largely elusive. In this study, we propose IUSMMT ( intersection-union survival mixture-adjusted mediation test ) to effectively examine the existence of mediation effect by fitting an empirical three-component mixture null distribution. With extensive simulation studies, our results demonstrate the advantage of this method over existing methods. We applied the method to ten TCGA cancers and identified multiple genes with mediating effects. Our results also demonstrate potential therapeutic targets for future clinical practice.

Developmental plasticity is the ability to generate different phenotypes in response to environmental input. Deciphering its genetic basis has potential to shed light on the origin of novel traits and adaptation to changes in environmental conditions. However, molecular studies are scarce, and little is known about molecular mechanisms associated with the formation of plastic traits. Here, we investigated the gene regulatory network controlling predatory vs. non-predatory dimorphism in the nematode Pristionchus pacificus and found that it consists of genes of extremely different age classes. We isolated mutants of the conserved nuclear hormone receptor nhr-1 with previously unseen phenotypic effects. They disrupt mouth-form determination and result in animals combining features of both wild-type morphs. In contrast, mutants in another gene, NHR-40, display altered morph ratios, but no intermediate morphology. Despite divergent modes of control, the two genes encode extracellular proteins that have no orthologs in Caenorhabditis elegans. An array of transcriptional reporters revealed co-expression of all tested targets in a pharyngeal gland cell, linking rapid gene turnover with morphological innovations. Thus, evolution of teeth and predation involved novelty at the level of genetic, cells and behavior.

Mitochondria are vital organelles inside the cell and contribute to intracellular calcium ( Ca2+ ) dynamics directly and indirectly via calcium exchange, ATP generation, and production of reactive oxygen species ( ROS ). Arrhythmogenic cardiac arrhythmias have been observed in experiments under abnormal mitochondrial depolarization. However, complex signaling pathways and calcium cycling between mitochondria and cytosol make it difficult to experimentally dissect out the underlying mechanisms. In the present study, we use a newly developed spatiotemporal ventricular myocyte computer model to investigate the mechanisms of calcium-dependent calcium alternans in cardiac myocytes. We find that the redox effect of ROS on ryanodine receptors and sarco/endoplasmic reticulum calcium ion pumps synergistically promote calcium excitation-contraction coupling. Due to their relatively slow kinetics, oxidized signaling and ATP do not play significant roles acutely in the genesis of the calcium calcium oscillations, but their roles can be significant during the long term, mainly through their effects on the activation of sarcosolic calcium pumps.

Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome ( HFRS ) is a zoonosis characterized by clinical features of fever, hemorrhage, and renal damage. China has reported over 1. 56 million cases with a fatality rate of nearly 3. 0%, accounting for 90% of the total reported cases worldwide. Therefore, it is necessary to improve our understanding of how anthropogenic activities ( e. g., precipitation, temperature, landscape ) and anthropological factors affect rodent reservoir dynamics. In this paper, we conducted a retrospective epidemiological study in Xi’an, the capital city of northwestern China, to investigate the association of rapid urbanization, water bodies and other factors on the spatiotemporal dynamics of HF RS from year 2005 to 2018. The results revealed an evident epidemic aggregation in the incidence of Hantaviruses ( HTNV and SEOV ), especially within the radii of 696. 15 m and 1575. 39 m, which represented significant thresholds.
