Our results also showed that geomatics approaches can be used for spatial and temporal studies to better understand the dynamic characteristics and supporting effective allocations of resources to formulate strategies for preventing epidemics.

Helicobacter pylori chronically infects the stomach of approximately half of the world’s population. Manifestation of clinical diseases associated with infection, including cancer, is driven by strain properties and host responses; and as chronic infection persists, both are subject to change. Previous studies have documented frequent and extensive within-host bacterial genetic variation. Here we combined whole genome sequence analysis of 39 clinical isolates acquired prospectively from a single subject at two time points and from multiple gastric sites. During the six years separating collection of these strains, this individual, initially harboring a duodenal ulcer, progressed to the loss of acid secretion due to frequent inter and intragenomic recombination. We identified 1, 767 unique single nucleotide polymorphisms ( SNPs ) in the Cag pathogenicity island ( CAGPAI ) protein and identified the genetic basis for modulation of inflammatory cytokine induction and morphologic diversification. The presence of subgroups with unique genetic and phenotypic properties suggest complex selective forces and multiple niches within the gut during chronic infections.

Soil-transmitted helminths ( STH ) cause significant morbidity in children and women of reproductive age. The World Health Organization ( WHO ) recommends preventive chemotherapy ( PC ) of at-risk populations with anthelminthics to control these infections. In Pemba Island ( Zanzibar ), the results of a survey conducted in 1994 in 12 schools estimated a prevalence near to 100%. This extremely high prevalence induced the introduction of PC in the island; initially, however, PC was not regularly administered because of difficulties linked to drug procurement and the interruption of the schistosomiasis programme. We conducted a study in 2021 using the same method as that used in 2011. Our results show that, despite its beneficial impact, both the prevalence and intensity of infections remain high. These results are probably due to a combination of irregular PC, climatic conditions favourable to the transmission, low sensitivity of T. trichiura to benzimidazoles, high population density and poor sanitation.

Chikungunya virus ( CHIKV ) is a re-emerging mosquito-borne alphavirus, which has rapidly spread around the globe thereby causing millions of infections. In this study, we examined the importance of the microtubule network during the early steps of infection and dissected the intracellular trafficking behavior. We observed two distinct trafficking patterns prior to membrane hemifusion. Whereas half of all the viral virions remained static during cell entry and fused in the cell periphery, the other half showed fast-directed movement before delivery to Rab5-positive early endosomes and predominantly fused at the perinuclear region. Disruption of this network reduced the number of infected cells, yet fusion was restricted to the periphery. Furthermore, follow-up experiments revealed that disruption of these two patterns impairs the delivery of viral genome to cell cytosol.

Bacteria use nucleotide second messengers to transduce external signals and translate them into a specific cellular response. Cyclic di-adenosine monophosphate ( c-di-AMP ) is the only known essential nucleotides. In addition to the well-established role of this second messenger in the control of potassium homeostasis, we observed that glutamate is as toxic as potassium for a strain of the Gram-positive model bacterium Bacillus subtilis. This study identified the amino acid transporter YbeC as the major glutamate transporter, and a mechanosensitive channel of small conductance ( YfkC ) resulting in a device for glutamate export. On complex medium, potassium and osmolyte toxicity are the main bottlenecks for the growth of B. subtils. Our results indicate that the adaptation to either glutamate or simple medium usually requires the simultaneous presence of multiple suppressor mutations that often affect potassium uptake and potassium biosynthesis, or glutamate metabolism. Moreover, the ability to grow on anaerobic conditions is an indication for infection with pathogenic bacteria.

Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) causes lymphomas and epithelial cell cancers. Though generally silent in B lymphocytes, this widely prevalent virus can cause endemic Burkitt lymphoma and post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorders/lymphomas in immunocompromised hosts. We have previously shown that the cellular proto-oncogene STAT3 prevents phosphorylation of Chk1, and thereby, suppresses activation of the intra-S phase cell-cycle checkpoint, a potent barrier to cell proliferation. This observation prompted us to examine the consequences on DNA repair since homologous recombination repair, the most error-free form, requires phosphoChk 1. By analyzing gene expression profiles of cancer lines derived from a wide variety of tissues, we now report that this defect also curtails DNA double strand breaks. These findings not only reveal how the tumor virus induces DNA replication stress as measured by RPA and ATR nuclear foci, but also provide the first genome-wide evidence for insertions resulting from synthesis-dependent MMEJ in human cells and expand the range of cancers that are likely to respond to synthetic lethal inhibitors.

Buruli ulcer is one of the 20 neglected tropical diseases in the world. It is a necrotizing skin disease caused by an environmental Mycobacterium Ulcerans. At least 33 countries with tropical, subtropical and temperate climates have reported Buruli. Majority of cases are spread across West and Central Africa. The mode of transmission is unclear, hindering the implementation of adequate prevention for the population. Currently, early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to minimizing morbidity, costs and preventing long-term disability.

The Cluster-of-Differentiation-44 protein ( CD44 ) is a versatile molecule that is involved in a variety of cellular processes, including inflammation, hematopoiesis, cell migration and cancer invasiveness. The protein consists of an ectodomain ( ED ), a single transmembrane domain ( TMD ) and a cytoplasmic tail ( CT ). In a similar way, microdomains can suppress the binding of the CT to cytoskeleton adaptors of Ezrin, Radixin and Moesin ( ERM ) family, which act as regulators of cell motility and differentiation. However, the molecular mechanism explaining how the protein is migrating into and out of lipid raft domains and its dependence on both palmitoylations and the presence of PIP2 remains, however, elusive. Here, we perform extensive molecular dynamics simulations to study the raft affinity and translocation in phase separated model membranes as well as more realistic plasma membrane environments. We observe a delicate balance between the influence of both factors on the phosphatidylinositol-4, 5-biphosphate ( Pip2 ) lipids. Our results shed light on how membrane translocations and peripheral protein association can be controlled by both protein modifications and membrane composition.

Cooperative living systems regularly achieve cooperative emergent functions that individual organisms could not accomplish alone. The rafts of fire ants ( Solenopsis invicta ) are often studied in this context for their ability to create aggregated structures comprised entirely of their own bodies. While similar protrusions are observed in cytoskeletons and cellular aggregates, they are generally dependent on morphogens or external gradients leaving the isolated role of local interactions poorly understood. Here we use an ant-inspired, agent-based numerical model to demonstrate that a set of ant interaction rules predicts the emergence of spontaneous protrusion growth in the absence of any long-range communication, and this directional motion facilitates the runaway growth of said structures. These results provide an example in which functional morphogenesis of a living system may emerge purely from local interaction at the constituent length scale, thereby providing an inspiration for the development of decentralized, autonomous active matter and swarm robotics.

Culex pipiens quinquefasciatus, which is widespread in tropical and subtropical regions, is an important species of mosquito vectors of public health concern. Infected mosquitoes transmit pathogens to other hosts, including humans, mammals, and birds, through blood feeding. Olfaction plays a vital role in the whole life cycle of mosquitoes, such as in their host-searching, mating, blood-feeding, egg-laying processes. The olfactory system is composed of various odorant receptors ( ORs ) and odorants-binding proteins ( OBPs ), but the molecular mechanisms behind these differences are still poorly understood. In this study, we screened for differentially expressed OR and OBP genes in female adult mosquitoes to investigate whether they play a role regulating the blood–feeding behavior of Cx. molestus. We found that OR5 and OR78 might be species-specific expressed genes that regulate the mosquito-borne behaviors, providing new targets for screening effective repellent compounds.

The hippocampus encodes spatial information through a subset of pyramidal cells that fires action potentials when the animal is in a specific location within the environment—the place fields. These cells are thought to encode and store new memories by taking part in activity-dependent synaptic plasticity. However, the mechanisms underlying place field formation and stabilization have not been fully explored. Here, we present a computational model of the hippocampal CA1 network, which describes the formation, dynamics and stabilization of place cells. We show that although somatic disinhibition is sufficient to form a new state, dendritic inhibition is necessary for the stabilization of this state. Our model suggests that place cell stability can be attributed to strong excitatory synaptic weights and strong inhibitory synaptic activity. Finally, our model predicts that the interplay between excitsatory and synapses is essential to unravel the underlying mechanisms.

Molecular xenomonitoring ( MX ), the detection of parasite nucleic acid in the vector population, is recommended for onchocerciasis surveillance in elimination settings. In the years since the guidelines’ publication, several foci have eliminated the parasite and new studies have been published that add to this data. However, MX may have additional applications for control programmes but its utility is restricted by a limited understanding of the relationship between MX results and human prevalence. We conducted a systematic review of studies reporting the prevalence of DNA in wild-caught Simulium spp. flies and the corresponding proportion of microfilaria ( mf ) in humans. The primary objective of this review was to assess the sensitivity of MX for detecting communities with ongoing parasite transmission and to explore the factors that affect this sensitivity.

Leprosy is a chronic infectious disease caused by the obligate intracellular bacteria Mycobacterium leprae, with a 2018 global prevalence rate of 0. 2/10, 000 population. Brazil contributed to 92. 3% of the increase in new American cases from 2017–18. Clinical manifestations depend on the host’s genetic polymorphisms and environmental factors that modulate the quality of immune response, ranging from the multibacillary disabling lepromatous form at the other end, where borderline forms in between. In fact, the lectin pathway of complement ( LP ) has long been recognized as favoring the establishment of infection and in leprosy progression. Despite their obvious importance, their roles played by these proteins have never been investigated. We investigated whether MASP1 gene variants and products are associated with susceptibility and to the different clinical forms of this disease. Our results suggest that the roles of MASPs are not well understood.

Nongenetic phenotypic variation has the potential to either slow down or accelerate the rate of adaptation. We show that it can speed up evolution in environments where available carbon and energy sources change over time. To this end, we use an experimentally validated model of Escherichia coli growth on two alternative carbon sources, glucose and acetate. On the superior carbon source ( glucose ), all cells achieve high growth rates, while on the inferior, only a small fraction of the population manages to initiate growth. Consequently, populations experience a bottleneck when the environment changes from a superior to an inferior. Our model predicts that greater gene expression noise can increase the likelihood that cells arise which host very large numbers of beneficial mutations. Central to the adaptation-enhancing principle we identify is the ability of noise to mitigate population bottlenecks, particularly in fluctuating environments. This principle may apply to a broad range of environments and organisms.

Dengue virus ( DENV ) is an enveloped, single-stranded positive sense RNA virus that infects ~400 million people worldwide every year and is transmitted by the Aedes aegypti and aedes albopictus species of mosquitoes. While most studies have focused on viral RNA-host protein interactions in mammalian cells, there has been less investigation of proteins that form complexes with the viral 3’UTR and regulate infection in mosquito cells. In this study, we have employed an intracellular biotinylation-based approach called RaPID to identify protein complexes that interact directly or indirectly with viral and host cellular proteins. We found that Loqs interacts with both the full-length and subgenomic viral RNAs, and the RNAi pathway, a central immune defense mechanism in the mosquito host that is responsible for recognition and degradation of viral mRNA.

Temporal environmental variations affect diversity in communities of competing populations. In particular, the covariance between competition and environment is known to facilitate invasions of rare species via the storage effect. Here we present a quantitative study of the effects of temporal variations on coexistence in two-species and in diverse communities. Four scenarios are compared: environmental variation may be either periodic ( seasonal ) or stochastic, and the dynamics may support either ( global competition or not ( local competition ). We show that seasonal variations yield shorter persistence time because they allow for rare sequences of bad years.

Functional non-coding ( fnc ) RNAs are nucleotide sequences of varied lengths, structures, and mechanisms that ubiquitously influence gene expression and translation, genome stability and dynamics, human health and disease. Here, to shed light on their functional determinants, we seek to exploit the evolutionary record of variation and divergence read from sequence comparisons. The approach follows the phylogenetic Evolutionary Trace ( ET ) paradigm, first developed and extensively validated on proteins. We assigned a relative rank of importance to every base in a study of 1070 functional RNA, including the ribosome. In turn, these clusters mapped functional regions for catalysis, binding proteins and drugs, post-transcriptional modification and deleterious mutations. As a result, smoother structural distributions of evolutionary important nucleotides improved functional site predictions. This work is broadly relevant to studies of structure-function in ribonucleic acids. Additionally, this generalization of ET shows that evolutionary constraints among sequence, structure and function are similar in structured RNA and protein. RNA ET is currently available as part of the ET command-line package.

We investigate the source detection problem in epidemiology, which is one of the most important issues for control of epidemics. Mathematically, we reformulate the problem as that of identifying the relevant component in a multivariate Gaussian mixture model. Specifically, our approach provides a statistically well-defined region ( s ) of nodes that are likely to be the spreading origin of an observed process, accompanied by a corresponding posterior probability. The proposed method is demonstrated within the context of a 2000–2002 cholera outbreak in the KwaZulu-Natal province, South Africa.

Recent state-of-the-art multiplex imaging techniques have expanded the depth of information that can be captured within a single tissue sample by allowing for panels with dozens of markers. Despite this increase in capacity, space on the panel is still limited due to technical artifacts, tissue loss, and long imaging acquisition time. To address this, we propose computational approaches to determine the amount of shared information between markers and select an optimally reduced panel. We show that all methods perform adequately and can re-capture cell types using only 18 of 25 markers ( 72% of the original panel size ). The correlation-based selection methods achieved the best single-cell marker mean intensity predictions with a Spearman correlation of 0. 90. Using the proposed methods shown here, it is possible for researchers to design more efficient and generalizable multi-encoder imaging panels that maximize more information retained in a minimum image size.

Leptospirosis is the most widespread zoonotic disease worldwide, especially in tropical and subtropical regions. In some carrier animals, such as rodents, leptopires colonize the proximal tubules of the kidney and are excreted in the urine. After that, they rapidly reach organs via hematogenous dissemination. The kidneys, lungs, and liver are the major organs affected by severe disease, but some patients progress to Weil’s disease ( weil's disease ), a severe multiple organ failure and some of them die. It has attracted attention in recent years to the relationship between lepticosis and chronic kidney disease. We investigated the dynamics and histopathological changes in both the kidneys and the hamsters subcutaneously infected with pathogenic bacteria. Our results suggest that the renal distribution of pathogenicity during the acute phase ( septicemic phase ) can influence the extent of tubular atrophy, leading to CKD.

Talaromycosis is a serious regional disease endemic in Southeast Asia. It is mainly concentrated in the southern region, especially in Guangxi, and causes considerable in-hospital mortality in HIV-infected individuals. Currently, the factors that influence the death of HIV/AIDS patients with T. marneffei infection are not completely clear. Existing machine learning techniques can be used to develop a predictive model to identify relevant prognostic factors to predict death and appears to be essential to reducing mortality. In this study, we prospectively enrolled 27 hospitalized AIDS patients from January 2012 to June 2019. The average mortality rate was 13. 3% ( 256/1927 ) and the most common complications/coinfections were pneumonia ( 68. 9% ) followed by oral candida, 47. 5%, high-density lipoprotein cholesterol ( HDL ), hemoglobin ( Hb ) levels. Deceased patients showed higher CD4/CD8 ratios, aspartate aminotransferase, urea levels, uric acid ( UA ) Levels, lactate dehydrogenase ( LDH ) level, creatine kinase levels and C-reactive protein ( CRP ). Septic shock and respiratory failure were the main predictive features, but the other three models were ruled out due to poor performance.

Human toxocariasis has been identified as an under-diagnosed parasitic zoonosis and health disparity of significant public health importance in the United States due to its high seropositivity among socioeconomically disadvantaged groups, and possible links to cognitive and developmental delays. Through microscopy and quantitative PCR, we detected that Toxocara eggs are widespread in New York City public spaces, with evidence of high levels of contamination in all five boroughs. The Bronx had the highest contamination rate ( 66. 7% ), while Manhattan, the borough with the lowest contamination, was the predominant species. Moreover, infective eggs were only found in playgrounds, where over 70% of eggs recovered in embryonic form and the most egg burden ( p = 0. 0365 ) were found. We also found that feral or untreated cats represent a significant source of environmental contamination. These results indicate that cat feces are an important source for the parasite. Additional studies are needed to address the potential risk of infection within NYC communities.

Envenoming by scorpions belonging to the genus Tityus is a public health problem in Tropical America. One of the most medically significant species is T. trivittatus, which is known to occur from southwest Brazil to central-northern and eastern Argentina. In this work, we studied the lethality, composition, antigenicity, and enzymatic activity of venom from a population found further north in urban areas of eastern Paraguay, where it has caused serious envenomation of children. Our results indicate that the population is of medical importance as it produces a potently toxic venom with an LD50 around 1. 19 mg/kg. Venom neutralization in preliminary mouse bioassays was complete when using Brazilian anti-T. serrulatus antivenom but only partial when used Argentinean ant-toxin Tt1g. MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry indicated a significant ( 8. 14% ) genetic differentiation between the Argentinianan and Paraguayan populations. Proteolytic activity by zymography and peptide identification through nESI-MS/MS also point out that population-specific proteases may exist in T. trivitattus. A time-calibrated molecular phylogeny of mitochondrial COI sequences revealed that while some sodium channel toxins are shared, including β-doxidase-2g, others are population specific. Altogether, toxinological and genetic evidence indicate a distinct cryptic species.

Bat-pollinated flowers have to attract their pollinators in absence of light and therefore some species developed specialized echoic floral parts. These parts are usually concave shaped and act like acoustic retroreflectors making the flowers acoustically conspicuous to the bats. Acoustic plant specializations only have been described for two bats and one other bat-dependent plant in South East Asia. Moreover, acoustic traits have never been compared between flowers belonging to other pollination syndromes. To approach these questions, we recorded a dataset of 32320 flower echoes, collected from 168 individual flowers, from 12 different species. 6 of these species were pollinated by bats, 6 species by insects or hummingbirds. We analyzed their spectral target strength and trained a convolutional neural network ( CNN ) on the spectrograms of the floral echoes. Our CNN was able to classify the 12 plant species, both bat and otherwise, using only one echo/spectrogram. The higher classification performance of flowers can be explained by the lower variance of their morphological features.

Schistosomiasis is a neglected tropical disease caused by parasitic worms of the genus Schistomosoma and it is prevalent in many parts of Africa, Asia ( e. g., China ), and South America. In China, all infections are due to the intermediate snail host, Oncomelania hupensis, which is amphibious rather than aquatic and associated with high moisture microhabitats. The snail habitats can be categorized into three types in China: ( i ) marshland and lake areas, ( ii ) mountainous and hilly areas and ( iii ) plain areas with waterway networks. Snail data ( N = 15, 000 ) from two types of snail habitat ( lake/marshland ) in Anhui Province, a typical endemic area, were collected together with 36 environmental variables covering the whole province. Twelve different models were built and evaluated with indices, such as area under the curve, Kappa, percent correctly classified ( PCC ) and sensitivity and specificity. We found the presence-absence models performing better than those based on presence only. However, those derived from machine-learning, especially the random forest ( RF ) approach were preferable with all indices above 0. 90. Distance to nearest river was found to be the most important variable, while the climatic variables were more important.

Giardia duodenalis causes giardiasis, a major diarrheal disease in humans worldwide whose treatment relies mainly on metronidazole ( MTZ ) and albendazoles. The emergence of ABZ resistance in this parasite has prompted studies to elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying this phenomenon. We first determined that the iron-containing cofactor heme induces higher mRNA expression levels of flavohemoglobin ( gFlHb ), which is likely linked to an antioxidant, pharmacokinetic mechanism of resistance to the compound. Molecular docking analyses predict favorable interactions of the two compounds in the presence of these compounds, whereas LC-MS/MS analyses of reaction products showed that these molecules are indirectly oxidized to its sulfoxide by superoxide generated from the NADH oxidase activity. Interestingly, we find that this drug is able to produce the sulfone-susceptible clones transfected to overexpress the drug than the parent clones. Collectively these findings indicate a role for the enzyme in AB Z metabolism and its role in resistance.

The assimilation, incorporation, and metabolism of sulfur is a fundamental process across all domains of life, yet how cells deal with varying sulfur availability is not well understood. We studied an atypical growth phenotype in yeast, in which organosulfur auxotrophy caused by deletion of the homocysteine synthase Met17p is overcome when cells are inoculated at high cell density. Our results show that cells can cooperate to achieve sulfur fixation, indicating that the collective properties of microbial communities facilitate their basic metabolic capacity to overcome sulfur limitation.

Juvenile hormone ( JH ) acts as a gonadotrophic hormone stimulating insect vitellogenesis and oogenesis. Paracellular transport of yolk proteins through intercellular channels ( patency ) in the follicular epithelium is a developmentally regulated and evolutionarily conserved process. However, the mechanisms underlying the opening of the pency opening are poorly understood. Using the migratory locust Locusta migratoria, we report here that jH-regulated remodeling of zonula adherens ( ZA ), a belt-like junction maintaining physical linking between follicle cells, controlled the formation of patencies in zonal epithelial cells of adult females. We also show that the jh-induced remodel of Za disassembly resulted in disassociation of Partitioning defective protein 3 ( Par3 ) via a signaling cascade including G protein-coupled receptor ( GPCR, small GTPase Cell division cycle 42 ( Cdc42 ) and atypical Protein kinase C ( aPKC ). This study provides new insight into the mechanism underlying jusquiterpenoid-dependent pacyllogenin transport and egg production.

Alcoholic-related liver disease ( ALD ) is the third leading preventable cause of death in the world and one of the major chronic liver diseases worldwide. It accounts for ∼ 500, 000 deaths annually worldwide, representing a huge financial and healthcare burden on society. The harms related to Alcoholic result in 2016 in some 3 million deaths ( 5. 3% of all deaths ) worldwide with more than 2 million cases in USA. In sufficient quantities, it can potentiate important liver disorders over time such as alcoholic liver fibrosis and cirrhosis ( ALC ). Later, after a long period of liver-cell injury, the liver becomes mostly scarred, which can progress to liver failure and eventually to alcohol-overused liver cancer. Here, we use data from the Danish National Patient Registry ( NPR ) covering the entire population of Denmark during nineteen years ( 1996–2014 ) to examine if it is possible to identify patients likely to develop ALF or aLC based on their past medical history. We perform an in-depth analysis of a knowledge discovery approach by using high-dimensional statistical and machine learning techniques to extract and analyze patient data. Consistent with the late diagnoses of ALLD, our findings highlight the potential of this approach to discover relevant upstream and downstream diagnoses that represent its progression into a more complicated situation.

During critical periods of brain development, neurons exhibit juvenile plasticity in which connectivity can be modified in response to sensory inputs. However, the mechanisms underlying this developmentally programmed dendrite regeneration and whether it shares common machinery with injury-induced regeneration remain largely unknown. In this study, we report a crucial role of the Drosophila miRNA miR-87 in the regeneration of adult-specific neurons. We show that the transcriptional repressor Tramtrack69 ( Ttk69 ) is a functional target for miRs-88-mediated repression, and that this expression is elevated in C4da neurons during the larva-to-pupa transition. Our findings thus support the idea that developmental and injury induced regeneration share a common intrinsic mechanism to reactivate neuronal connectivity.

Vδ2 T cells are unconventional lymphocytes that are intrinsically reactive to malaria due to their activation by low-molecular weight phosphoantigens produced by Plasmodium falciparum in an innate-like manner, without prior antigen exposure or processing. In contrast to acute malaria, chronic malaria is associated with a decline in both the frequency and the ability to produce pro-inflammatory cytokines in response to parasite antigen. We hypothesized that CD16/FcγRIIIa engagement might be a second pathway of activation that may be activated by opsonized malaria antigen in chronically malaria-exposed individuals. Here we demonstrate that in the wake of frequent malaria exposure, the TCR is highly activated, and that this response is independent of the antigen presenting molecule Butyrophilin 3A1. Together, these results indicate that the innate and adaptive immune cells of malaria retain the capacity for antimalarial effector function, in cooperation with the humoral immune response.

A detailed understanding of protein function often requires an accurate description of the structure and dynamics of a protein. Here, we introduce DEER-PREdict, a software program to predict Double Electron-Electron Resonance distance distributions as well as Paramagnetic Relaxation Enhancement rates from ensembles of conformations. The software is open source ( GPLv3 ) and available at github. com/KULL-Centre/DEERpredict and as a Python PyPI package pypi. org/project/deER PREdict.

Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli is one of the top aetiologic agents of diarrhea in children under the age of 5 in low-middle income countries ( LMICs ). The lack of point of care diagnostic tools for routine ETEC diagnosis results in limited data regarding the actual burden and epidemiology in the endemic areas. We evaluated the diagnostic sensitivity and specificity of Rapid LAMP based Diagnostic Test ( RLDT ) for detection of E. coli in stool in a resource-limited setting. This study included 324 randomly selected stool samples from children with moderate to severe diarrhea ( MSD ) at selected health facilities in Lusaka District of Zambia. Our results show that the R LDT is sufficiently sensitive and specific and easy to implement in endemic countries where such simple assays are critically needed.

Longitudinal intervention studies with repeated measurements over time are an important type of experimental design in biomedical research. Due to the advent of “omics”-sciences, longitudinal studies generate increasingly multivariate outcome data. Analysis of such data must take both the longitudinal intervention structure and the multi-factorial nature of the data into account. The ASCA+-framework combines general linear models with principal component analysis and can be used to separate and visualize the effects of different experimental factors. However, this methodology has not yet been developed for the more complex designs often found in longitudinal interventions, which may be unbalanced and involve randomized interventions. Here we describe a new methodology, repeated measures ASCAA+ ( RM-ASCA+ ), and show how it is used in the analysis of both randomized and non-randomized studies. Tools for both visualization and model validation are discussed. This approach can facilitate easier interpretation of data from longitudinal clinical trials.

We study the time evolution of symptoms ( signs ) with some defects in the dynamics of a reaction network as a ( microscopic ) model for the progress of disease phenotypes. To this end, we take a large population of reaction networks and follow the stochastic dynamics to see how the development of defects affects the macroscopic states of the signs probability distribution. We start from some plausible definitions for healthy and disease states along with a dynamical model of signs and diseases by a reverse simulated annealing algorithm. The healthy state is defined as the sum of mutual information between a subset of signal variables and the response variables. A disease phenotype can be defined with two parameters controlling the rate of mutations in reactions and accepting mutations that reduce the objective function. This allows us to obtain the accuracy of diagnosis in different stages by using a probabilistic model.

The transmission of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 ( SARS-CoV-2 ) is dependent on the amount of virus present in the environment surrounding the susceptible host, and/or the proximity between susceptible and infectious host. Here, we developed a within-host and aerosol mathematical model and used it to determine the relationship between infectious virus and total RNA in both environments. We found that infectious viral shedding early in infection correlates with transmission events, shedding of infectious viruses diminishes late during the infection and high viral RNA levels late after infection are a poor indicator of transmission. Our results can guide interventions.

The relationship between the diversity in one community and another is called β-diversity, an idea which has led to numerous indices and coefficients which seek to quantify it. Here, we address this problem by leveraging an additional and often available source of data in presence-absence studies: the total number of independent samples taken from each community, i. e. the sampling depth or effort. Building on the same intuition as the estimation of total species from a species accumulation curve, this approach provides unbiased estimates of the overlap between two stochastically sampled communities.

Chagas disease ( CD ), caused by the protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi, continues to be an important cause of illness, disability and death. It is essential and important to diagnose CD using laboratory tests in order to prescribe the best treatment and, this way, stop the progression of the disease and prevent its transmission. The World Health Organization recommends using two conventional tests for diagnosing chronic CD, based on different principles and the comparative clinical-type design of some studies. This systematic review and meta-analysis constitutes an input for their use.

The neurotransmitter dopamine impacts on a variety of cognitive functions ( e. g. learning, working memory, affective behavior ) that interact in complex ways. While learning demands very precise input- ( action- ) output-associations, motivation might be thought of as a more general, behavior modulating factor. Here we present a new computational model that simultaneously regards release, diffusion and uptake of dopamine, ( II ) considers multiple terminal release events and ( III ) comprises both synaptic and volume transmission by incorporating the geometry of the synaptic cleft. We were able to validate our model in that it simulates concentration values comparable to physiological values observed in empirical studies. Further, although synaptic dopamine diffuses into extra-synaptic space, we found different variability characteristics between the three settings, which may in part account for differences in the empirical observations. From a clinical perspective, different striatal dopaminergic signaling contribute to differential learning and reward processing, with relevant implications for addictive- and compulsive-like behavior.

Ticks, which are well-known pathogen transmission vectors, are long-lived, reproductively prolific, and can utilize a variety of hosts. Ticks also may remain attached to the host, feeding on host blood, for long periods. This degeneration may be caused by the increased concentration of ecdysone in the hemolymph during the fast feeding period and both autophagy and apoptosis occur. In this work, we first demonstrated the regulatory role of Rhipicephalus haemaphysaloides ( RhATG5 ) and the caspase gene expression peaks during a fast-feeding phase. We further demonstrated that high concentrations of 20E led to a cleavage of the protein by increasing the concentration and expression of Rhcalpains. Furthermore, high levels of intracellular Ca2+ were also upregulated in ticks treated with a high concentration. These results demonstrate that the degradation of tick salivary glands represents programmed cell death mediated by apoptotic bodies.

Yellow fever is a zoonotic disease caused by the yellow fever virus ( YFV ), a flaviviridae arbovirus infecting both humans and non-human primates ( NHPs ). It is currently endemic in 34 countries in Africa and 13 in South America, with the largest outbreaks occurring in the previously unaffected South-East Atlantic coast of Brazil in 2016–2019. While habitat fragmentation and land-cover have previously been implicated in disease transmission, their role in YYF has not yet been examined. We examined the extent to which vegetation, land cover, climate and host population predicted the numbers of months a location reported Y fever per year and by each month over the time-period. Two sets of models were assessed, one looking at interannual differences over a study period ( 2003–2016 ) and a seasonal model. Each was fit using hierarchical negative-binomial regression in an exhaustive model fitting process. Within each set, the best performing models, as measured by Akaike Information Criterion ( AIC ) were combined to create ensemble models to describe the differences in seasonal, and for the seasonally model, EVI, day temperature and rainfall amplitude. Our models explain much of the spatiotemporal variation in Yellow fever incidence and geographic extent.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder ( OCD ) is characterized by uncontrollable repetitive actions thought to rely on abnormalities within fundamental instrumental learning systems. We investigated the cognitive and computational mechanisms underlying Pavlovian biases on instrumental behavior in both clinical OCD patients and healthy controls. In specific PIT, participants learn instrumental behaviors ( typically associated with instrumental cues ) to gain reward or avoid punishment, and reduced responding in the presence of negative cues. Our results contrast with the increased PIT effects reported for another set of disorders, compulsivity, in which PIT is enhanced. A possible reason for the reduced PIT in OCD may be impairment in using the contextual information provided by the cues to appropriately adjust behavior, especially when inhibiting responding when a negative cue is present.

Pantothenate ( Pan, vitamin B5 ) is the essential cofactor for the synthesis of coenzyme A ( CoA ), but among the apicomplexans, only the coccidian subgroup has the ability to synthesize Pan. While the biosynthetic pathways for Pan synthesis are largely conserved across all branches of life, there are differences in the redundancy of enzymes and possible alternative pathways to generate Pan from the host. In this review, we summarize the recent advances in understanding the Pan biosynthesis pathways, and the suitability of these pathways as drug targets.

Membrane proteins represent a large subgroup of proteins, which are responsible for the substance transport and signal transduction across cell membranes. Currently, over 50% of the known drugs target membrane proteins. Therefore, studying the structure and function of these proteins is of high interest. Here, we propose a characteristic and predictive quantity, the membrane contact probability ( MCP ), to describe the likelihood of amino acids of a given sequence being in direct contact with the hydrophobic acyl chains of lipid molecules. We show that the parameter of this quantity is complementary to solvent accessibility in characterizing the outer surface of membrane protein, and it can be predicted with a machine learning-based method by utilizing a training dataset extracted from MemProtMD, a database generated from molecular dynamics simulations. As the first of many potential applications for membrane ( membrane ) protein structure prediction, our results demonstrate that this property is an essential property in the protein contact maps and structures.

The COVID-19 ( SARS-CoV-2 ) pandemic is mitigated by several non-pharmaceutical interventions, but it is hard to predict which of these are the most effective for a given population. We developed the computationally effective and scalable, agent-based microsimulation framework PanSim, allowing us to test control measures in multiple infection waves caused by the spread of a new virus variant in a city-sized societal environment using a unified framework fitted to realistic data. Our analysis highlights the benefits and limitations of various quarantine and testing scenarios.

A major limitation to understanding the etiopathogenesis of environmental enteric dysfunction ( EED ) is the lack of a comprehensive, reproducible histologic framework for characterizing the small bowel lesions. We hypothesized that the development of such a system will identify unique histology features for the disease, and that some features might correlate with clinical severity. Duodenal endoscopic biopsies from two cohorts, Pakistan, Zambia ) and North American children with and without gluten sensitive enteropathy ( GSE ) were processed for routine hematoxylin & eosin ( H&E ) staining and scanned to produce whole slide images ( WSIs ) which we shared among study pathologists via a secure web browser-based platform. A semi-quantitative scoring index composed of 11 parameters encompassing tissue injury and response patterns commonly observed in routine clinical practice was constructed by three gastrointestinal gastroenterologists, with input from Eed experts. The authors used this index to assess its reproducibility, by applying it to two distinct cohorts with suboptimal growth recruited from distinct geographic locations where E. coli is prevalent. This index should be useful in future clinical and translational studies of this widespread disorder, which might be caused by multiple contributing processes, in different regions of the world.

One of the most interesting questions in evolutionary biology, social sciences, and economics is the emergence and maintenance of cooperation. A popular framework for studying cooperation ( or the lack thereof ) is game theory, which is frequently used to model interactions between “rational” decision-makers. Here we introduce a new game-theoretic setting called transparent games, where each player has a certain probability of observing the partner’s choice before deciding on its own action. By means of evolutionary simulations, we demonstrate that even a small probability in the transparent game substantially changes the evolutionary successful strategies. Our results have implications for studies of human and animal social behaviour, especially for the analysis of dyadic and group interactions.

Telomeres are repetitive DNA:protein elements that protect the ends of linear chromosomes and prevent their recognition as double-stranded DNA breaks. As a consequence of the “end-replication problem”, telomerase shorten with every successive cell cycle and such shortening ultimately limits the proliferative capacity of cells, by eliciting a cell-cycle arrest that acts as a stringent tumour suppressive mechanism. Telomere dysfunction during crisis leads to large-scale genomic rearrangements from which cells can escape by activating a telomre maintenance mechanism ( TMM ) that rescues cell viability but drives clonal evolution and cancer progression.

Toxoplasma gondii is an obligatory intracellular parasite that belongs to the phylum Apicomplexa. Upon contact with the host cell, rhoptry and microneme proteins are released in order to promote parasite entry by driving the formation of a tight parasite-host cell adhesive membrane structure ( termed the moving junction ) within which the parasite rapidly replicates. Dense granules are secreted in a constitutive manner during parasite replication and play a crucial role in modulating host host metabolic and immune responses. While the molecular mechanisms triggering these secretory organelles release upon parasite adhesion have been well studied, the mechanisms regulating their secretion have not been elucidated. Here, we investigated the role of the small GTPase Rab11A, a known regulator of exocytosis in eukaryotic cells. Our data revealed an essential role for Rab 11A in promoting the cytoskeleton driven transport of dense granule and the release of their content into the vacuolar space. Moreover, by live imaging we observed a polarized accumulation of viral and transmembrane protein trafficking and localization at the apical pole of extracellular motile and invading parasites suggesting that apically polarized delivery of cargo regulates early secretion of parasite cargo.

The stimulation of a single neuron in the rat somatosensory cortex can elicit a behavioral response. The probability of such a response does not depend appreciably on the duration or intensity of the constant stimulation, whereas the response probability increases significantly upon injection of an irregular current. Biological mechanisms that can potentially suppress a constant input signal are present in both neurons and synapses and seem ideal candidates to explain these experimental findings. Here, we study a large network of integrate-and-fire neurons with several salient features of neuronal populations, including cellular spike-frequency adaptation, experimentally constrained numbers and types of chemical connections endowed with short-term plasticity, and gap junctions. Numerical simulations of this model indicate that cellular and synaptic adaptation mechanisms alone may not suffice to account for the experimental results if the local network activity is read out by an integrator. However, a circuit that approximates a differentiator can detect the single-cell stimulation with a reliability that barely depends on either the length or the intensity, but that increases when the irregular signal is used. This finding is in accordance with the results obtained for a regularly-spiking excitatory cell.

Human skin is continuously exposed to environmental DNA damage leading to the accumulation of somatic mutations over the lifetime of an individual. Mutagenesis in human skin cells can be also caused by endogenous DNA damages and by DNA replication errors. The contributions of these processes to genome instability in the skin of healthy humans has so far not been accurately assessed because the low numbers of mutations from current sequencing methodologies preclude the distinction between sequencing errors and true genome changes. In this work, we sequenced genomes of single cell-derived clonal lineages obtained from primary skin cell samples of a large cohort of individuals across a wide range of ages. We show here that UV-induced base substitutions, insertions and deletions are prominent even in sun-shielded skin. Our analysis also highlights the interplay of environmental and endogenous factors in facilitating genome stability and carcinogenesis.

Clonorchiasis is a neglected tropical disease and a public health issue in endemic countries. In Vietnam, an in-depth analysis of risk factors for the condition is missing up to now. This study aimed to determine the prevalence of C. sinensis infection in rural communities in northern Vietnam. A cross-sectional survey was conducted in 4 communes in Yen Bai and Thanh Hoa provinces. The overall prevalence was 40. 4%, with commune prevalences ranging between 26. 5% and 53. 3%. Using a simple random sampling approach, stool was collected from 841 participants over 6 years old for coprological examination, a questionnaire measured knowledge, attitudes, and practices with regard to the disease in 757 participants. Univariable logistic regression models were run to identify risk factor for infection with the fish-borne trematode Clonorrchitis. These results demonstrated a high prevalence ( 40% ) of infection. Thus, control measures including, mass drug administration for persons with chronic infections, specific health education activities should be developed for risk groups in the endemic areas.

Skin problems cause significant sickness in communities with poor living conditions, but they have received less attention in national or global health studies because of their low mortality rates. In many developing regions, the prevalence of parasitic skin diseases among schoolchildren is not reported. Previous studies thus have attempted to identify risk factors for these conditions using the frequentist approach. To our knowledge, reports of scabies, tungiasis, and tinea prevalence among children in southern Ethiopia have not been compiled independently. We conducted a cross-sectional survey of 864 school-aged children aged 7–14 years from the Wonago district of the Gedeo region in northern Ethiopia. Using a frequentism and Bayesian approach, we found that almost three-fourths of children had at least one type of skin problem and boys were at higher overall risk than girls ( adjusted odds ratio [aOR] 1. 55 ). Washing legs and feet with soap daily was identified as a protective factor for each skin disease. The findings suggest the need to improve children’s personal hygiene via health education by schoolteachers and health workers.

Pathogenic mycobacteria actively dysregulate host immune signalling pathways during infection to drive the formation of permissive granuloma microenvironments. Dynamic regulation of host microRNA ( miRNA ) expression is a conserved feature of infection across host-pathogen pairings. Here we examine the role of miR-206, a member of the muscle-associated myomiR family and characteristically associated with myoblast differentiation and muscle development, in the zebrafish model of M. marinum infection. We find that the increased neutrophil response and reduced bacterial burden caused by infection is dependent on the Cxcl12/Cxcr4 signalling axis. Together, our data illustrate a pathway through which pathogenic miobacterial infections induce host microbial microRNAs to suppress their signalling and prevent their recruitment.

Robustness in developing and homeostatic tissues is supported by various types of spatiotemporal cell-to-cell interactions. Although live imaging and cell tracking are powerful in providing direct evidence of cell coordination rules, extracting and comparing these rules across many tissues with potentially different length and timescales of coordination requires a versatile framework of analysis. Here we demonstrate that graph neural network ( GNN ) models are suited for this purpose, by showing how they can be applied to predict cell fate in tissues and utilized to infer the cell interactions governing the multicellular dynamics. Analyzing the live mammalian epidermis data, where cell tracks are given as inputs, we discover distinct neighbor-specific rules that depend on the region of the body. This approach demonstrates how the graph network framework is powerful for inferring general cell interaction rules from live data without prior knowledge of cellular signaling involved.

Cancer is a complex and heterogeneous disease and the second leading cause of death worldwide. Although medical advances have made possible earlier diagnosis and more effective treatments, researchers still face many critical challenges for cancer drug resistance, combinatorial drug treatment optimization and personalized cancer therapy design. A number of studies have been conducted to understand the regulatory mechanisms between miRNAs and genes comprehensively. However, such methods fail to capture the context-specific miRNA-gene regulatory relationship. In this study, we present a tensor sparse canonical correlation analysis ( TSCCA ) method for the explorative analysis of matched mi RNA and gene expression data of multiple cancers with a focus on identifying cancer-shared and specific miR-expressed modules with better biological interpretations and statistical significance. We present an efficient block-coordinate descent algorithm to solve this problem.

Synaptic efficacy is subjected to activity-dependent changes on short- and long time scales. While long-term changes decay over minutes, long changes last from hours up to a lifetime and are thought to constitute the basis of learning and memory. Both plasticity mechanisms have been studied extensively but how their interaction shapes synaptic dynamics is little known. In this study, we use numerical simulations and mathematical analysis of a calcium-based model to study changes in synaptic efficacy induced by calcium and postsynaptic activity. We find that the model implementing known synaptic short time dynamics in the calcium transients can be successfully fitted to synaptic data obtained in visual-and somatosensory cortex. Interestingly, the impact of spike-timing and firing rate changes is different in both cortical areas considered here. Our findings suggest that both synaptic depression and synaptic potentiation are together tuned to adapt their effects to area-specific activity statistics such as firing rates.

Bats are the natural reservoir host for a number of zoonotic viruses, including Hendra virus ( HeV ) which causes severe clinical disease in humans and other susceptible hosts. Information on the early host response to infection in vivo is lacking and there is no comparative data on responses in bats compared with animals that succumb to disease. In this study, we performed whole proteome analysis of lung tissues from experimentally infected Australian black flying foxes and ferrets at 12, 36 and 60 hours post exposure. Viral antigen was detected at 60 hpe and was confined to the lungs whereas in ferret there was evidence of widespread viral RNA and antigen. The mRNA expression of IFNs revealed antagonism of type I and III IFN and a significant increase in the chemokine, CXCL10, in bat lung and spleen following infection. Gene Ontology ( GO ) enrichment analysis revealed species specific expression patterns that may be associated with the differences in infection outcomes. GO analysis also revealed enrichment of the type II IFNF signaling pathway in both bats and mice.

Genome-Wide Association Studies ( GWAS ) have identified thousands of genomic risk factors and generated insights into disease etiologies and potential treatments. However, the apparent heterogeneity of diseases which has not been sufficiently recognized by these studies is frequently unknown. We present CLiP ( Correlated Liability Predictors ), a method to detect heterogeneity in a single cohort of cases and controls collected by the Psychiatric Genomics Consortium. The method is mathematically and through simulation that among homogeneous cases generated by a liability threshold model, significant anti-correlations are expected between otherwise independent predictors due to ascertainment on the hidden liability score. In the presence of heterogeneity from distinct phenotypes, confounding by covariates, or mislabeling, these correlation patterns are altered predictably. Our method extends to two additional association study designs: CLIP-X for quantitative prediction in applications such as transcriptome wide association, and CLIP-Y, where there is no clear distinction between cases.

Cell culture remains as the golden standard for primary isolation of viruses in clinical specimens. In the current practice, researchers have to recognize the cytopathic effects ( CPE ) induced by virus infection and subsequently use virus-specific monoclonal antibody to confirm the presence of virus. Considering the broad applications of neural network in various fields, we aimed to utilize convolutional neural networks ( CNN ) to shorten the timing required for the detection of influenza-induced effects and to improve the assay sensitivity. A deep CNN model was developed to train the CNN in evaluating the changes of the infection data. The performance of our model, examined by images of MDCK cells infected by six other non-influenza viruses, was 100%. Hence, a simple CNN was established to enhance the identification of flu virus in the clinical practice.

Varicella zoster virus ( VZV ) is a member of the alphaherpesvirus subfamily and is responsible for causing chickenpox and shingles. We have identified a novel viral RHIM in the capsid triplex protein, open reading frame ( ORF ) 20, that acts as a host cell death inhibitor. Like the human cellular proteins that stabilise the necrosome in TNF-induced necroptosis, and the viral proteins in murine cytomegalovirus that inhibit cell-death signalling, we have shown that the ORFs20 RHI is capable of forming hybrid amyloid complexes with human ZBP1, a cytoplasmic sensor of viral nucleic acid. Although VV can inhibit T NF-mediated neoprotosis by inhibiting cell cell proliferation, this inhibition does not appear to be necessary for the virus to proceed via this pathway. Therefore we propose that this motif is important for preventing the inhibition of apoptosis.

Infectious disease risk is driven by three interrelated components: exposure, hazard, and vulnerability. For schistosomiasis, exposure occurs through contact with water, which is often tied to daily activities. Water contact, however, does not imply risk unless the environmental hazard of snails and parasites is also present in the water. By increasing reliance on hazardous activities and environments, socio-economic vulnerability can hinder reductions in exposure to a hazard. In this study, we combined parasitological, survey and ecological data from 13 villages along the Senegal River to better understand the relative contributions of exposure and hazard to the presence and intensity of S. haematobium re-infection. We found that hazard ( Ʃwi = 0. 95 ) was the most important component of the infection, followed by vulnerability, respectively, controlling for demographic variables. Model averaging quantified associations between each infection outcome and indices of risk, revealing a positive association between hazard and infection presence ( OR = 2. 49, 95% CI 1. 12, 1. 97 ) and a negative association with exposure intensity. Our findings underscore the linkages between social and environmental ( hazard ) processes in acquiring and accumulating infection.

Lassa fever ( LF ) is one of the most prevalent hemorrhagic fevers in humans. The World Health Organization has recently declared LASSa virus ( LASV ) as a priority pathogen for accelerated research leading to a renewed international effort to develop relevant animal models of disease and effective countermeasures to reduce LF morbidity and mortality in endemic West African countries. A limiting factor in evaluating LF is a lack of well characterized animals outside of those based on infection with the strain Josiah originating form Sierra Leone, circa 1976. Here we genetically characterize five recent LassV isolates collected from the 2018 outbreak in Nigeria. Three of them were further evaluated in vivo and despite being closely related to the same spatial / geographic region of Nigeria, only one was lethal in strain 13 guinea pigs and non-human primates. Additionally, this isolate exhibited atypical pathogenesis characteristics in the NHP model, most notably respiratory failure. These results suggest that there is considerable phenotypic heterogeneity, which could account for differences between subclinical and lethal LF infections.

Schistosoma mansoni is an intravascular parasite that alters the hematological and biochemical parameters in humans. It is a major public health problem with more than 260 million people infected worldwide and of which, over 90% of the cases occur in Africa. A comparative cross-sectional study was conducted at Haik Primary Hospital North-East Ethiopia, from February to April 2021. One hundred and eighty study participants consisting of 90 S. manson infected adults and 90 apparently healthy controls were recruited using systematic random sampling method. Socio-demographic characteristics and other variables were collected using questionnaires. Stool sample was examined microscopically to detect the parasite infection using direct wet mount and Kato Katz technique. The intensity of infection was rule out in apparently normal controls. Moreover, Erythrocytic sedimentation rate ( ESR ) was significantly elevated among S. mansons infected patients than healthy control. On the other hand, the median eosinophil count, mean cell volume ( MCV ) and mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration ( MCHC ), total cholesterol ( MPV, and platelet volume ) were significantly lower.

Antibodies targeting the envelope glycoprotein E2 are associated with delayed disease progression, and these antibodies can also facilitate spontaneous clearance of infection in some individuals. Since a goal of HCV vaccine development is induction of high titers of anti-E2 antibodies, it is important to define the mechanisms underlying suboptimal antibody responses in natural infection. By staining lymphocytes with a cocktail of soluble E1 ( sE ) proteins directly ex vivo at multiple acute infection timepoints, we found that most chronically infected individuals demonstrate low-titer antibodies. We then used this data to identify optimal bait antigens to detect circulating antibodies in vivo. Our data demonstrate that a rationally-selected antibody cocktail is more sensitive than single antibodies for detection of circulating antigenically-distinct B cells.
